reviewText: Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ is a visual novel about an awkward protagonist that finally realizes his lifelong dream of going to Japan. A very novel idea that was not given away at all from the title. AwkProtag says that he is going to be staying with two friends that he met over the internet while in Japan. Thinking they are male friends, he is very surprised to find that the friends that he has been talking to over the internet are actually cute Japanese girls! What's better is that the house they're going to stay in doesn't have any parents in it because of the convenient emergency business trip" excuse that is so popular in these kinda stories. AwkProtag is now happy that he is staying with these girls
date: especially since they are both very attractive to him. Makoto is the older sibling with big breasts and a nice temperment. Akira is your typical flat-chested tsundere. There's literally no more depth to these characters
recommended: except for the fact that they know ridiculous amount of trivia of Japanese history/landmarks. Of course
hoursPlayed: you have the option of falling in love with either of these girls. For the first (and only) playthrough
voteText: I ended up with Makoto. I didn't enjoy this game really and was only fun for the sheer ridiculousness of AwkProtag and the scenarios that he would get into. Eventually AwkProtag goes home and that's the end of the story.\n\nAlso
helpfulPercent: this game has very liberal usage of elipses. Like
votesHelpful: I'm talking whole dialogues where the only thing the characters say are ".........." to each other. Like
votesTotal: literally the use of these were so ridiculous that I couldn't take it anymore. I wanted to quit so bad. This was a hellish experience and something that will haunt me for the rest of my life. I wasted 5 hours playing this VN and all I have to show for it is ....................."

reviewText:
Gomenasai, my name is Ken-Sama.

I’m a 27 year old American Otaku (Anime fan for you gaijins). I draw Anime and Manga on my tablet, and spend my days perfecting my art and playing superior Japanese games. (Disgaea, Final Fantasy, Persona series)

I train with my Katana every day, this superior weapon can cut clean through steel because it is folded over a thousand times, and is vastly superior to any other weapon on earth. I earned my sword license two years ago, and I have been getting better every day.

I speak Japanese fluently, both Kanji and the Osaka dialect, and I write fluently as well. I know everything about Japanese history and their bushido code, which I follow 100%

When I get my Japanese visa, I am moving to Tokyo to attend a prestigious High School to learn more about their magnificent culture. I hope I can become an animator for Studio Ghibli or a game designer!

I own several kimonos, which I wear around town. I want to get used to wearing them before I move to Japan, so I can fit in easier. I bow to my elders and seniors and speak Japanese as often as I can, but rarely does anyone manage to respond.

Wish me luck in Japan!

reviewText:
What can I say? As one of the most popular VN's on steam, I had to give it a try since I got it in some weeaboo game bundle. I was not disappointed.
You play as a hopeless 'murican Otaku who is born with a horrible facial disfigurement, that causes him to have no eyes, and his mouth to be skewed to the right side of his jaw. He learns to overcome his disfigurement, and also finds true love.
He learns many valuable life lessons along the way, including:

1. Dragging a 12 year old Japanese girl straight to the Hentai section of a Doujinshi store in the heart of Akihabara makes an excellent first, second, or even third date.
2. Girls with big boobaru's find peeping tommery irrisistable.
3. That green stuff isn't pesto.
4. When a girl tells you she isn't angry, it means she is just a liiiittle bit ABSOLUTELY LIVID.
5. Girls with small boobaru's like a guy that can chug a coffee loaded with enough salt to cause a hypertensive crisis.
6. Whenever you find yourself alone with 2 sisters, it will always lead to them desparately clambering for your jank.
7. The more incapable you are at talking about your feelings, the more attractive girls will find you.

Overall I say give it a chance if you are even a little bit interested in Anime, Manga, and/or Japanese culture. I think it's probably a good intro for some people into the world of Visual Novels, even if the dialogue can be laughable at times. Protip: As long as you don't care about spoiling one of the most heart felt moments in weeaboo entertainment media history, watch part 13 of the Game Grumps playing the game on youtube (start watching at 12:28). https://youtu.be/ck1YiXiHci0?t=12m27s

10/10 would walk in on a 12 year old girl undressing again.

reviewText:
Might aswell write an actual review for this.

Go! Go! Nippon! ~Squiggly Lines~ is probably the most known cheesy visual novel on steam. I'm talking about cheesy ones, not actually good ones.
You play as Randomerican, some otaku from america who has been interested in japan ever since he watched an anime. One day he finally gets the chance of his life and goes on a trip to japan where he can stay with two japanese friends he met over the internet. Upon arrival you notice how the hero barely cares, seeing how he was expecting the two friends to be males instead of females. In my honest opinion he should probably be more careful with his decisions or he might aswell would have gone to japan and never get back home. And to his luck, the two girls are home alone while you are staying at their place. What a cooiincideeence. We all know where this is going.
As you stay with your one week waifus you get to learn about japan and it's culture. Yay! This is actually not too bad of an idea, but the execution is not the best. At all. If the main character wasn't acting like the average tourist all the time (WOAH! A TRAIN!) the novel would be way more enjoyable. But on the other hand it might just be a better idea to just go to a nearby tourist office, grab a brochure about japan (if they have those, I don't visit those) and be done with it. But I guess this game has a story. Somehow?
During the game you get to make your own decisions. Sometimes. And instead of just being there like in Sakura Spirit they actually affect the ending. It adds at least some sort of diversity, but it's literally either love girl one or love girl two.
And don't forget, like every poorly translated anime visual novel, you get your daily dose of random fap material. Like really, the two moments where that happens have no relation to the story at all. It's just there to beg for your curiousity.
Ramen/10.

reviewText:
Tokyo-Tour-Guide with Romance

A nice little visual novel, with a little bit of history/modern society on japanese culture.
It might be interesting for people who are interested in visting Tokyo, which you can somewhat simulate in this game.
Also nice little romance aspect, but don't expect some grand plot with a lot of character development.
It`s more of a lighthearted and short visual novel.

If you need a rest from grand story driven visual novels, with a lot of dialogue and many choices. And looking for something less-serious and lighthearted, I recommend checking it out (especially if it's on sale).

reviewText: I recommend this game for those who wish to take an interest in traveling to this. I have gone to Japan many times before and this game reminded me of my guide as a service i had in 2010. They showed me many of these areas before and provided their share of interest. Playing this game also reminds me of the different foods though. Thoroughly a good game guide to a basic level. however I recommend that if you do travel choose between Kansai and Narita. The one in 2010 took Narita as It does say here. It provides a nice insight to the areas many do want to visit and obviously quite nice they put the USD Converters to Yen because it is that helpful. Believe it or not, this game is great. At a good price. I recommend it 7-9/10 in it's own way. I just wish there were more travel locations and foods. The game mentions the usual attractions and a story between you and these two. However replayable is necessary due to limited days. Locations include popular shrines, Akihabara, Shibuya's Hachiko, and Mt. Fuji. In it's right, it's worth the buy and on average it's short but educational. Plus those who want to take a look into Japan, this is a more accurate version with the matters of scenery, travel, and places. If you do go and don't know anyone, grab a guide and trust me you won't regret it. Just remember though don't think too high and bring a lot of cash. Trust me this game may keep the rate the same but in RL, the exchange rates can change so fast during hours of the day. If I were to give it a score. 6.4-8 due to it's playthrough, limited area, good story, dialogue, but it lacks location, extended travel days, and covers one area. Yet as it is a game, I can say it did it's job right with the guides. So for in total the average would be a 7.5-7.8. Although this game was released in 2011, adding it here will help those who didn't know much. Either way enjoy the game for what it is. I know I did, just wished that we had another version, different guides, different area, you know. Needs that litle extra. Still good in it's own right. Enjoyable.

reviewText:
Go Go Nippon is a special kind of torture. Writing this, I’ve not quite gotten over the shock of the sheer abhorrency of its dialogue, the dryness with which random geographical trivia spills out of its characters mouths, and the painful lengths it goes to pander to its audience.

Arriving from overseas to spend a week in Japan with two almost complete strangers you met in an online chat room, Go Go Nippon greets you by laying all its perverted cards on the table. We meet Makoto, the cheerful, ditzy airhead whose only defining feature are her enormous, perfectly framed breasts and cooking skills so poor her concoctions very nearly kill our protagonist (if only we’d been as lucky).

Then there’s Akira, the bashful would-be-tsundre who exists for the purpose of manufacturing drama when she’s not reciting tourist guides and blushing profusely every time your character speaks. And what a character are globetrotting protagonist is, taking seemingly every chance to point out the varying ways Makoto and Akira are and aren’t cute, and missing no opportunity to walk in on them changing and proceeding to engage in lengthy small talk instead of swiftly exiting the room.

The character interactions in Go Go Nippon are so self indulgent and excruciatingly bland that I began to feel real, physical pain at every new line. I’ve never cringed so hard at any piece of media in my life, and now feel it will be weeks before my facial features will be able to recover from the image of pure disbelief and disgust that has been carved into them by this game.

I can’t imagine what sort of person Go Go Nippon is actually for, as it fails at being a history lesson on Japan, a well written drama, or even sufficiently perverted enough to satisfy a crowd looking for that kind of fix. It’s a shallow regurgitation of facts wrapped in excruciating dialogue that goes far enough so as to be immensely uncomfortable and unapologetic in its sexual pandering, but without even a molecule of tastefulness or purepose. Playing it made me hurt. It made me want to scream. It made me feel like I needed a shower. If there’s a universe where this game is worth your time I hope I never find it.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
Disappointing.

The narrative consists of a naive, barely post-pubescent foreigner whom, although speaks 'perfectly fluent' Japanese, knows nothing about any of the standard Japanese tropes such as vending machines everywhere etc. The game also includes ridiculous sexualomantic scenes which are inserting with less subtly than an elephant in a human man costume. There's just nothing in the story to latch on to at all.

There is a huge lack of art in this game which is a huge shame considering that the imagery is its main draw. Each location consists of 2 or 3 different pictures of the area, and is constantly cycling through images you have already seen. The game is constantly alluding to food or objects\phenomena that just isn't shown even with a simple pop-up graphic or anything.

The only innovative thing here is there are google maps links to some of the locations you visit, which I haven't seen in a game before.

reviewText:
TL;DR: 3kawaii5me

This game is the epidome of excellence. I feel as if I understand the characters emotions on a cosmic level. Even though I have known the two sisters in this game for such a short time, I feel as if I have known them for 2 years, possibly 2 years and 5 months. The writting in this game is shrektacular; it's as if Hideo Kojima himself came down from the heavens and blessed this game with his awe-inspiring writting ingenuity.

The visuals in this visual novel are also quite breath-taking, I've never seen such brilliant stylizations since Crysis. Already you're immersed in the lives of these two sisters that you're living with for a week as they tell you useless and useful information about the various regions of japan.

My 10 years of experience in anime could not prepare me for the level of kawaii I was about to witness; a ground-breaking visual novel that gripped my heart one moment, and shattered it the next. If this game was a person, it could emancipate an agictated ostrich by playing bethoven's 5th with an empty pringles can and a pair of chopsticks. There is no reason for you to not own this masterpiece already.

reviewText:
Go! Go! Nippon is a very cute, all ages visual novel in which you take your first trip to Japan. It does a good job of introducing you to certain elements of Japan, and even has Japanese text along with the English so you can hone your skills at the same time. It features two sisters, that are members of your host family, that show you around Japan, and at the same time you are able to woo whichever one you desire. You will want to play through this game at least twice to enjoy all of the content.

The game was created by Overdrive, the company behind such eroge titles as Kira*Kira, DearDrops, and others. So even though it is short compared to those titles, Go! Go! Nippon! features the quality they are known for.

I highly recommend this game having played through it entirely prior to being on Steam, and will now be replaying it again. My only hope is they add trading cards and achievements one day.

reviewText:
It was a harsh, unbearable day of summer; one of many I’ve experienced, and one of many to come.  July 8th, 1968.  I’ve been fighting in the Vietnam War for four years at this point, and the Viet Cong had started to invade our shelters frequently.  With each time I flee from oncoming attacks, I grow more and more ready for the end of my life, ready to accept it with open arms.  With each raid from the north, I get slower, weaker, and less determined.  Today was the day I truly felt I would die.  I thought to myself, if it’s not this ungodly heat that kills me, it’ll be the rifle of one of those commies being stuck right into my mouth, finally giving me a sweet release from this cruel life.
Sirens and gunfire blare in the distance.  They’re coming once more, I can feel it.  As civilians and even some cowardly soldiers surrounding me flee for their lives in the opposite direction, I drop my weapon, slowly walking out towards this disastrous storm of an army with my arms spread, ready to embrace the pain they inflict upon me.  This is it, I thought. This is how my life if taken from me – with mothers and children screaming in each other’s arms, villages burning down, and hundreds of guns pointed right at me.  I shut my eyes tight, ready to hear one last sound of gunfire before I drop to the ground.
But… it stops.  The sound of silence is so peaceful, you could hear a pin drop from miles away.  The sound of flames suddenly eases itself, and I can hear a bird chirping in the distance.  I open my eyes slowly, suddenly appalled with what I’m witnessing right before me.  Each and every soldier previously rushing towards the base was now face down in the mud, covered in blood, their soulless bodies resting peacefully.  My eyes flutter as the sun peeks over the clouds and makes a blue sky.  That’s when I see it; a heavenly figure emerging from the great beyond, smiling sweetly, cradling the dead bodies and letting them turn to dust in her divine little hands.
>ohshititsmakotomisaki.jpg
Suddenly realizing my embrace is still open, Her Gorgeousness graces over too me and wraps me in her lovely arms, caressing every last fear in my body.
“Now, my child…” she whispers sweetly, “Finish what I have started, and you may be granted my presence once more.”  Without another word, her beautiful hourglass figure floats back into the heavens, fading into nothingness.  The United States sure as hell didn’t win the Vietnam War, but I’ll be darned if that didn’t bring back to me every last ounce of motivation I had ever had.  I slaughtered every last commie to come my way, was awarded the Medal of Honor, and finally returned home to my beautiful country.
Decades have passed since then, but I never forgot what happened on that truly blessed day.  From that day onwards, I would pray to Makoto on every occasion I got to show my undying love for Her Gracious Lady.  I pray every night to thank her for a wonderful day, before every meal to thank her for her plentiful supper, and every morning to thank her for even giving me the opportunity to wake up and experience a new day.  I was neglected and laughed at for my beliefs, with people dismissing me as someone who obsessed over a fictional character.  What fools, Lady Makoto won’t save their ungrateful selves when they're burning in anime hell.  My faith remained unchanged, as I knew one day she would come back to me and reward me.
Most people ask their deities for a sign, but I never asked mine for one.  I got mine in Vietnam, and I know that’s all I needed to know she would potentially reward me with a heavenly eternal life to grace right beside her.  Yet, through Our Precious Savior’s undying kindness, she did reward us with another sign – a sign in the form of a game known as “Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~”.  The most beautiful and greatest being in the history of all mankind now has physical proof of existence, and I could not stop crying tears of joy upon discovering it.  She promised me I would be granted her presence once more, but never in a million years would I have guessed it would be before I meet my due date.
This game changed my life.  It makes me more excited for the day My Makoto determines I have done enough for the world, and blesses me with the chance to live alongside her and her followers in the afterlife.  Until that day, I feel unbelievably privileged to have the opportunity to experience Her Gracious Lady at any time I wish to feel closer to my maker (under limitations of dialogue, of course, as no mortal being can withstand the greatness of Makoto at her full potential).
There are no words to describe how beautiful she is,
or how special she is, or my love for her.
To put these things into words would be to define them,
To quantify them, which means to limit them.
There would be a beginning and an end.
There is no definition fitting, nor any limit,
nor beginning or end to her beauty,
or to how special she is, or my love for her.
Make me your soldier, Makoto, for I am willing to serve you unconditionally.

reviewText:
I was gifted this game and was initially skeptical, as I hold no particular interest for Japan, Japanese culture or anime/manga. My curiosity was aroused though when I found out that during my virtual visit to Japan I would be accompanied by two young girls. They looked fresh-faced, despite the comedically large breasts/short skirt that one of the girls sports. The desire for love and to get a virtual waifu compelled me to give it a go. Who knows, perhaps I would enjoy a threesome with said sisters at the end of the game?

So, I started it up and lo and behold ran into my cute little senpais. My boner and willigness to play this game slowly evaporated though as Makoto spent at least 10 minutes explaining to me how the Japanese public transportation system works. I was getting more and more confused as she droned on about PASMO (http://www.pasmo.co.jp/en/ for more info) and the difference between that and SAIKU cards. Apparently PASMO cards can only be used in the Tokyo Metropolitan Area.  As she droned on and on I slowly got more frustrated and bored. After she explained to me the wonders of the card, in that you can scan it at the ticket machine without taking it out of your wallet (no I am not kidding, they acted as if this was the most amazing thing in the world) I decided to give up. I shut the game down, turned on incognito mode and watched Tentacle Fest 9 and I am the happier man for it.

A boring game with a misleading premise. Avoid at all costs, lest you too get sexually frustated and incredibly confused about the inner workings of Japanese public transport.

reviewText:
I was actually pretty excited about trying Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~
The premise sounded interesting, the fact that it would tell you facts about Japan was also interesting, and I thought perhaps it'd be a fun little story that would give you some knowledge of culture and such as you played.

First, what I liked:
The part about Japan facts was interesting, not everything was new to me, and half of the stuff you'd already know if you ever opened, you know, a brochure for Japan or watched an anime... but it was still interesting.
The graphics were nice, background as well as characters were well drawn.
I loved the idea for the VN, and loved that you could actually have it with Japanese text too.
The idea of having expenses added was interesting, but badly done and underused.
I guess if you're getting ready to visit Japan this would be cool.


Now, what I disliked:
While the graphics were nice, they were poor. Half the time you had sky shots with music/sound/text that would be like Oh

reviewText:
After seeing all the reviews in store page, I was baffled with the sarcasm so imma give a proper review for this visual novel.

First thing first, this is not AAA VN; with all the content in this game, $9.95 is reasonable enough. This VN is more focused on being a tourist guide and it did a good job for that.

For story, it has 2 routes, 1 for each heroines. It is divided into two part, Common Route and Heroine Route:

The Common Route is focused on providing tourist information on the location that you selected in the game. There are 5 destinations to choose, in which you choose one location per day. The information that are given by the heroine is simple yet very useful if you're going to Japan. It provides background information on the location, the adaptation of the area as time progress, and you get to know what's what in that location. You can go to 3 location max. The destination that you chose determine whose route you gonna take.

The Heroine Route is focused on romantic development for the heroine that you progressed. THIS IS WHERE I GOT FRUSTRATED BECAUSE OF THE CLIFFHANGER ENDING... ehm, ignore my fanrage. As a person that plays countless of eroges, visual novels and galge, I can say that the romantic part of this VN is under-developed but it has a lot of potential. The romantic development is fast-paced but it leaves you wanting for more. It might be a quick romantic trip, but the characterization is very good for this size of VN so I guess I can't complain about that.

The gameplay itself is pretty simple, you just read-click-read. A feature worth noting for this VN is the option to show Japanese text alongside English text, a very useful feature if you're planning on learning Japanese. The currency conversion is a pretty neat feature of this game as it allows you to set the rate of $/€ to ¥ and vice versa, it gives you an estimate of how many dough you might spend on the trip there (train fare can vary depending on which location you might stayed if you really come to Japan).

The art of this VN is quite good for its size, with the feature of upscaling to HD I can't even ask for more. Then again this is not AAA VN, the amount of CGs and sprite quality is decent enough.

All in all, I gave this game rating 7.4/10. It did a good job for being a tour guide, but then again, I DEMAND A SEQUEL FOR THIS GAME KMON WTF GIB ME A SEQUEL WITH MOAR H/E-SCENE AND PROPER ROMANCE + DEEP LOVE RELATIONSHIP WITH THE HEROINE !!!
ehm, ignore my fanrage. Definitely recommend this game (and planetarian ～ちいさなほしのゆめ～) for people that is interested in playing visual novel medium

reviewText:
Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ follows the journey of a severely autistic manchild as he takes a journey into a foreign land while trying to hide the fact that he is a sperglord. In a way, it is the Octodad of autism. Except instead of convincing others you're a human, you must convince them you are not an autist who spergs out over stupid Japanese ♥♥♥♥. And instead of doing the convincing, you watch helplessly as the protagonist you play as makes a fool of himself over and over again, while normal people somehow remain unaware that you are not one of them.

The entire game's design oozes with symbolism. The Yen to Dollar conversion system seems like a pointless waste of time at first, but really it symbolizes American exceptionalism. The game's inability to distinguish between read and unread text while skipping symbolizes depression. Mostly mine, as I spent money on this. The harem romance garbage symbolizes the ♥♥♥♥♥ on the game's store page art. See it? That doesn't even look like an exclamation point.

Truly the Evangelion of video games

Six out of five Lennys

reviewText:
Go! Go! Nippon! is a short Visual Novel based on the idea of someone visiting Japan for the first time.

Of course you as the main character speak really good Japanese, and is also an Otaku.
The story is mostly centered around you exploring Japan in the company of two girls who take turns going with you depending on where you decide to visit. The nudity tag doesn't really belong on this game but whatever.

Personally the story felt as if it was a bit lacking because of the nature of the premise: visiting Japan for the first time. There are few choices that you can make that make any difference and only two endings.

Overall it can be an entertaining game if you're in the right mood, just don't expect much from it. If you want to visit Japan though, it has cool features like being able to hit a button and see what that specific location looks like on google maps from a street view. I found this to be interesting as I wouldn't know exactly where to look for those specific attractions.

Though it's not amazing, it's still worth the playthrough twice if you get it at a discount on the base price.
If you're  VN lover, you'd probably rate it higher than my 5/10.

[This review is not based on the content in the DLC]

reviewText: If Propoganda was a game, this would be it. Honestly, why would anyone willingly play or enjoy this? There are just so many things that are wrong with this game, I don't even know where to start. The main character is blatantly ignorant about his own country of origin, is easily amazed at the most simple things like convenience stores. The Dialogue is cliché and circular and the characterization is non existant (hint: the player basically embodies the neckbeard stereotype and the two females are empty clichés devoid of any real characterization)\n\nIf you want to learn about japan, read a book.

reviewText:
This is a very mild recommendation. It comes with a bunch of IFs. Consider this game...

IF you study Japanese : having the dual subtitles in English and Japanese is a great way to practice. (Personally, it is the main reason I bought that game for)
IF you can't go to Japan and are interested because anime : then you will learn quite a few true things beyond clichés. And if you went there (I did), you'll be reminded in an unusual and kinda fun way.
IF you don't mind a visual novel with less fanservice and less dating sim elements than most. The game clearly wanted to be educationnal first, and offer a love story second.
IF you can cope with some scenes being pointlessly long.
IF you can cope with the main character being a (good-hearted) complete idiot.
IF you don't mind the price, which is slightly too high in my opinion.
For me, the idea of practicing my Japanese and being reminded of my trip made this game a decent experience. I also liked that the game felt more romantic because there was less fanservice than in many visual novels.
...There definitely is some, but we don't really go into the world of ridiculous in which girls trip and fall breasts on your face all the time. If you see what I mean.

If you are not in a similar mindset as I am, you might find this game boring. Hopefully this review can help you figure out if you'll get something out of this technically below average game.

reviewText: This VN seems like it was produced by the government Bureau of Tourism, trying to convince you to choose Japan for your next vacaction.  There is a tally of the fares, tickets, admissions, and meals as if it would help you to understand how much to budget for a trip.  It is mostly meaningless since the protagonist gets most of his meals and lodging for free from the girls.\nThe only choices are picking 3 of the 7 sightseeing destinations for daytrips.  I won't bother replaying the game to visit the others sites.  The chatter between the 3 characters is inane.  Artwork of other people are missing.  The entire VN seems to churn through the same 3 poses, with a few variations of expressions, and hardly any variety of costuming.  It is sad that so many Manga lovers would skew this VN to a positive rating just to booster their passionate interest.

reviewText: This game is a bit of a mixed bag. On the one hand, it presents a rather awkward dating scenario between yourself and a pair of Japanese girls who host your stay in Japan. Let’s hope you like girls then. It doesn't seem to cross the developer’s minds that you might not. Anyway, the far more interesting activity, in my humble opinion, is the exploration of Japan and some of it’s main tourist attractions. That's really quite good! So if you can live with the cringe-worthy dating part, then the game wins a recommendation.

reviewText: It was immediately obvious, from the moment that I started this game
date:
that the main character is an intolerable LOSER. He is amazed at such small things as Japanese toilets, Japanese power outlets, Japanese rugs, Japanese bathtubs. The fact that there is a card that can be used to automatically pay for access to a train just blows him away. He thinks that only happens in Japan. His ultimate dream was to simply set foot on the island of Japan, to be a tourist. He almost crapped his pants because he was allowed to sleep in the Japanese-styled guest room. He has the enthusiasm and attention span of a chihuahua.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=371464594

reviewText: If I were to describe it to someone I would say it's an informational 'game'. Where two sisters take you around and you learn about different areas of Japan with a little flirting with the sisters. The 'romance' plot seems a little out of place and I wouldn't recommend the game if that's what you're looking for. But if you want something that's educational / informative about the history of some of the more popular areas of Japan then give it a shot.

reviewText:
You get to go to Japan, guided by a Mature Goddess and a Tsundere Loli...
And there's only three people - You, the goddess, and the loli!
Everytime you go to a city, one of them will happily join you in your visit...
And your relationship with them gets stronger and stronger!
The whole week, it's just the three of you living your lives and finding out about Japan...
And that's just the freaking HALF of it!
It's not all about Japan, of course....
But also about your epic virtual love story with your new oh-so too kawaii friends!
As it progresses, it just becomes more dramatic and intense...
With an ending that is based on YOUR decisions!
So what are you waiting for? Hurry and get it....
So that you can enjoy this lovely, brilliant work of a god on your own!

reviewText: This little visual novel might actually make you nostalgic if you ever been to Japan, or could be very informative if you're planning to visit. If you don't mind the ultra cheesy story that actually goes nowhere (but tries to), one perfectly dumb protagonist that goes to Japan while being clueless about everything. They tried to add a little fanservice and flavor by making you stay with two females but don't expect much besides decent amount of major tourist spots and japanese reading practice as a side option. Quite short, has cards, fun little cheesy visual novel as a snack.

reviewText:
For all intensive purposes, this game is an overseas love story.
I thought it was really cool how although it is your typical story game, you really do actually learn things.
It's a much cheaper trip to Japan from the comfort of your own home. One of the coolest features imho was the view photo" button as you're traveling. The View Photo button opens up the exact place you're at on google maps where you can freely go explore the place you're in and how it looks in real life. Pretty neat.

reviewText:
For a limited time offer, not only do you get one waifu, but two waifus at 50% off!

This game teaches a some what wide range of tourism in Japan. This includes minor basic vocabulary of tourism in Japan, tourism details of specific spots such as Akihabara, Shibuya, Shinjuku, Ginza, Ikebukuro, Asakusa, and finally, Kyoto. Also covers some important foods found in Japan, curry rice, omu-rice, okonomiyaki, and much more. Not only does it give you a taste of Japan, but does so in it's own visual novel way mixed with romance and comedy.

For this limited sale, it is definitely worth it for the empty souled 2D-lover, aspiring Japanese future-tourist, or/and curious buyer.

reviewText:
Let me tell you about this game. It's not even about the game anymore. It's about how it starts:

You're a cool guy. You've never watched anime, except for like, Dragonball or whatever. But that was cool, right? Then you get to high school and you think to yourself, man, all these ♥♥♥♥in weebs. what a bunch of total losers. You leave high school. Life goes to ♥♥♥♥ but you get netflix. You start watching anime on netflix because you've watched literally everything else on there. It dawns on you. You like it. You actually love anime. You feel the transformation. The hunger for superior Japanese content. Words you used to use as a joke, you now use in all seriousness. You start watching hentai. Even the weird tentacle stuff. You realise you've become the weaboo you always made fun of and joked about. You buy Go Go Nippon. The transformation is complete. You're a 22 year old neet with no ♥♥♥♥ing prospects except this game. Well ♥♥♥♥ing played.*

5/7 can't wait to play.


*at least 80% of this happened to me

reviewText:
take your trip to japan through your monitor now !
tradition, clothes, foods, monument and places. everything's here, in Go! Go! Nippon! my first trip to japan, with beautiful tour guider, good illustration, warming atmosphere, and many more.

okay, here we go ...
before reading, remember, this is my review. based on my point of view. other people might, or must, have a different point of view.

first time playing, this game gave us a quiz about japanese currency. yep, how much 1usd worth in japanese yen?
here, we played as a tourist from europe. damn, i don't know he want to visit japan that badly. after arriving at the airport ( finally, after taking a quiz at the airplane ), he met with 2 qt young lady. the one named makoto ( older sister, the one with big ♥♥♥♥ ) the other one named akira ( younger one without ♥♥♥♥ )

i'll tell you, makoto can't cook. but she can do house joob better, and has a great figure ( her body, i mean ) plus, she's a real kind person with a warmth aura that'll make you fall for her.
aand, there's akira. makoto's younger sister. she's the real, pro cook in her family that can't do house job correctly. plus she's a tsundere ( seriously, who'll fall for a tsundere with no ♥♥♥♥. come on man ... ) but she's cute. cuter than makoto. while makoto have a hot body, she has a cute face ( but still, no ♥♥♥♥ )

you'll stay at their house, plus their parents are off the town. they'll accompany you in this journey, telling you about SUICA, many kind of vending machines, sushi restaurant ( you know, that one with the rotating table. ♥♥♥♥♥♥ awesome ). you'll spend your times walk around the temple, shopping district, arcade center, and etc. japanese awesome places.

as the time flow, you'll know many things about history of all japanese temple. as well as the statue and some historical district in japan, the tradition changes, clothes, and how important some japanese people are. you'll know the different between the old japan and the 21st century japan that we know now ( building changes, street, festival etc. )

like any other VN, you'll have to choose some kind of place that'll be your route of this game. every place that you choose will trigger some event ( i assume you ga uys are already know how VN score counting system works ). with that you can choose the route you want, and not, to get to your version of happy ending ( i suggest makoto ending, akira's ending doesn't give you any good since she has no ♥♥♥♥ )

make sure to play this game alone, cz you don't want your parents to see makoto go half naked, right? ( especially your father, careful he might get a boner )

overall this game is totally worth buying it.
one thing i think this game needed, achievement. yep, looking forward to it.

anyway there's my review, i know peoples point of views are different. this review is based on my point of view, you might want to read other's review b4 buying this game.
but once again, this game i stotally worth buying it

pls rate up if you found this review helpful, thanks for reading.

reviewText:
This is a review for the vanilla version, without the 2015 DLC.

Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ is a simple VN from Overdrive and MangaGamer that's part romance game and part travelogue. You play an unassuming and rather naive weeaboo visiting Japan for the first time. On your arrival you find out that A. the two guys you had befriended online and arranged to stay with are actually cute teenage girls and B. their parents are out of town for the duration of your stay (of course!). This brings about a surprising but not unwelcome predicament as you're suddenly sharing a roof with two very attractive women.

The two girls have distinct but frankly rather unremarkable personalities. Makoto
recommended: is nicer and more cheerful and generally just a bit moe
hoursPlayed: and can speak pretty good English.  She's good at housekeeping with the awful exception of cooking. She also has a much nicer- ahem- physique
voteText: compared to her sister. Akira
helpfulPercent: the younger
votesHelpful: is your basic tsundere
votesTotal: though perhaps more mellow and reasonable than some. She can barely speak any English at all
votesFunny: which doesn't really affect the plot that much since your character is mostly bilingual. She is also a great cook
commentsCount: to balance out for her lackluster housekeeping skills and attitude. I would say she's also the more fleshed out of the two
column16: with a slightly more satisfying arc.\n\nThe romance of the game is simple
column17: and who you end up with in the end is based purely on who you spend more time with
column18: determined by where in Tokyo you go explore. See
column20: the girls will take it upon themselves to give you tours of the city
column21: giving you lots of great information about the places
column23: and customs. This is also the area where the game shines
column24: as the presentation is both interesting and informative
column25: and basically gives you a lot of pointers if you ever actually want to visit the country in real life.\n\nAs for the aesthetics
column27: I actually quite like the character design. It fits very well with the nature of the story and theme
column28: and is pretty memorable. The backgrounds can also be pretty gorgeous
column29: which is unsurprising since it's basically giving you a tour of famous sites. The music was pretty forgettable for me
column31: I honestly don't remember much about it).\n\nThis is a good game to pick up if you're interested in Japanese culture and/or visitng Japan. If you're just looking for a general VN
column33: but there are lots of better ones around. I would recommend buying this
column34: but only when it's on sale."

reviewText: Go! Go! Nippon is a nice little bit of infotainment that educates as it temporarily alleviates the crushing loneliness that is your reality. You play as an insufferable weeaboo that embarks on his first trip to Japan, where you'll be staying with two young Japanese girls who apparently get off on the social stigma of harboring a greasy foreigner. The two serve as your guides to The Land of the Rising Sun, lecturing you on Japanese history and culture while you wonder whether there's an H version of this game. You'll learn a lot, you'll grow as a person, and in the end, you lose if the underage one doesn't fall in love with you. Incorporation of Google Maps with photos was a brilliant touch.

reviewText:
I have always wanted to go to the wonderous land of Japan. Ever since I began to watch animes such as Naruto and Attack on Titan (OTAKU PRIDE!! ヽ(｀Д´)ノ ). So I ended up buying this game to learn even more about Japan and Japanese culture for my future trip.

This game is amazing, you get to plan exactly how your trip will go by visiting major hotspots (I recommend going to Akihabara ^_^). You also get to see plenty of famous Japanese dishes like Omurice and Ramen (YUM!! P:). Everyone speaks Japanese in the game too, to immerse the player more. Now I can plan for my trip and practice my Japanese at the same time, which is really sugoi* (sugoi means awesome in Japanese). And the women in Japan are gorgeous as shown in this game. When I go to japan, I hope I too can stay with two beautiful sisters.

As for the H-scenes though, they are fairly vanilla and lackluster in general. Nothing like the Violent ♥♥♥♥♥ Inferno VN that I usually play, but I can't really complain since I got this for planning purposes. So over all, this is a really solid VN that I highly recommend.

reviewText: Go! Go! Nippon! ~ My First Trip to Japan ~ is a cute little visual novel, where you explore many of the most famous landmarks in Japan, in the company of Two sisters you befriended online and whom you stay with during your weeklong visit. Awkward situations arise, giving this game the feel of an anime, and as you explore more of Japanese culture and learn about it's history, your relationship with your new friends develops as well. All in all, it was a very cute game, with some funny dialogue and a couple of situations that gave it an anime feel. I thoroughly enjoyed the game, even though the playthrough was very linear. You can make some choices as to where you want to visit; However, a large part of the playthrough will be visiting specific areas in Japan, such as Kyoto. I don't regret picking this game up in the slightest and would like to see a sequel even, to further explore Japanese culture and history, as well as to continue to character development and relationship between the Protagonist, and the sister.

reviewText: *This would-be professionally made" review will mostly cover Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ Ver. 2015
date: as that version has twice the amount of content compared to this base game version*\n\nRest assured
recommended: this game is an odd one - well
voteText: but odd because it provides an education on the Japanese culture for those actually interested in it. And make no mistake when people say this game fills a small gap in a Japanophile's wet dream - that is pretty much true. But there's another reason I decided to make a positive review of this game: my enjoyment for this game was (and still is) two-fold.\n\nVisual novels - hereby referred to as VN - often suffer from poor localisation
helpfulPercent: cringeworthy translation and/or lack of content (and with it
votesHelpful: replayability). This is the case with most VN's published by Sekai Project and Winged Cloud. Granted
votesTotal: they do provide great eyecandy but the characters
votesFunny: the story and the quality of the dialogue fall really flat as a result - hardly anyone buys Nekopara or a Sakura game for its story.\n\nGo! Go! Nippon however is a different case. Sure
commentsCount: the story is pretty much non-existent besides the "Gaijin-protagonist-visits-Japan" synopsis but all the things that are pretty much thrown away in Sekai Project's and Winged Cloud's VN's have been handled with love - and it shows. You'll get to know the Misaki sisters Akira and Makoto as you venture through six locales (ten
column16: if you play the 2015 version) and educate yourself with some Japanese culture and its history. You'll also grow fond of them up to the point where you'll have to choose whom you'll want to be with the most between the two sisters – which is pretty heart-breaking
column17: all things considering.\n\nThe education aspect in Go! Go! Nippon is another differentiating factor: you get a sufficient amount of information about the locales and Japan's history in a reasonably bite-sized package while still managing to be fun and not boring
column18: being accompanied by either of the Misaki sisters during the trip.\n\nWith the content being twice as large as the base game
column19: you'll find yourself visiting your virtual Japan again and again as there are multiple endings that you can achieve – two for each girl
column20: as opposed to having only one in the non-2015 version.  And let's not forget the quality of the localisation: it's surprisingly okay. It's not something you'd cringe on the first line or on the first five minutes you invest in the experience
column21: which is a huge win in my eyes.\n\nAlso
column22: there are a few things added to Go! Go! Nippon! Ver. 2015 not present in the old base game. The E-Mote System certainly adds character and life to Akira and Makoto as they smile
column23: stare at you in surprise and give you the "you w0t?" face. You can also check the locale's via Google Maps as you visit them in-game to further deepen your research and plan on your would-be IRL trip to Japan or just look at them in curiousity.\n\nGo! Go! Nippon! (especially the Ver. 2015) is a surprisingly great experience
column24: despite the "weeaboo" target audience this VN is aimed mostly towards. It adds some educational elements to the experience while also remaining what it is – a visual reading experience

reviewText:
It's good visual novel and it's has top notch writing quality just like any other Overdrive visual novel.
The story it's self is kind of boring but the humor in the writing leaves me with some giggles at end.

For a interactive tour guide, there's very few pictures to deal with.
Some parts of the dialog should have added a different picture/scenery to make the visual novel stand out more.

The Soundtrack in this visual novel really does bring back the nostalgia of Kira*Kira, An awesome visual novel from Overdrive. By the way, they reused most of the soundtrack from their other leading visual novels.

On the bright side, I did learn some interesting facts about Japan from this visual novel.

This is a good start for Mangagamer to bring more visual novels to Steam.

reviewText:
Disclosure: This was the first visual novel I've ever played, and perhaps this genre of game just isn't my thing.

That being said, I played through the entire experience and found it to have heart, good art design, and catchy background music!

The real plus is all the information you get as a first-time 'tourist' in Japan.  If you are planning a trip to Japan, I think this would be a fun and enjoyable primer.

For what it is, I would recommend this!

(rant time: I am not sure where Steam provides any value regarding reviews for this game as nearly all of the ~900 reviews of this game are spam, inappropriate, or just plain unhelpful drivel.  Reviews of those natures should be removed as it makes it too difficult to get a relevant and insightful review of this game on Steam.)

reviewText:
I am required to review all the weeb games that Alex made me play in exchange for the game off my wishlist.

This game was pretty awful in all honesty.

Your character is some idiot American whose dream is to travel to Japan. He is surprised to find out that his tour guides are actually two sisters, and he'll be staying in their home. There are lines like 'Okay, I'm a gentleman, I'm a gentleman' or 'I'll protect you, I'll be your shield' I think that proves how bad this ♥♥♥♥ is on its own merit.

You are escorted around Tokyo and Kyoto by the two girls, with a lot of typical faire anime ♥♥♥♥/references/blah. You know the cliches.

Your character conveniently catches both girls in embarrassing situations. Funny huh. One naked just out of the shower or w/e, and the other getting dressed. The dialogue in these scenes is the worst part about them.

Your character upsets the younger sister but...makes it up to her by confessing his love? They've known one another for 4-5 days at max? Sure, makes sense.

Best part of the game is being able to quickly skip through the dialogue.

Do not play this game. Ever.

reviewText:
This game is my first visual novel, so I can't compare it to others.  As a standalone experience, it's interesting.  You play a tourist coming to Japan for the first time, staying with a couple of brothers you met on the Internet.  The brothers turn out to be sisters - shocking! and also, you forgot to ask and apparently never shared a pronoun - and in among the inevitable progress to seduction (you only get to fall for one of them per game) there's a lot of first-time tourist information about visiting Tokyo and the environs, along with light language lessons and some good practical advice about tourist mistakes to avoid.  Which is actually pretty cool. I've never been, but now I'm quite curious.

There's no nudity; the Steam game tag is wrong on this score.  You manage to catch each sister minus some clothing by forgetting to knock and then forgetting to look away or close the door, but the pictures are PG-13 in nature, if not intent.  Apart from that it's all about True Love, and in fact the game gets embarrassed pretty easily, like if anything ever even remotely suggests that people might be physically attracted to each other.  The number of awkward-pause ellipse screens to click past [...] is staggering.

There are two endings (one each for matching with each of the sisters), and if you check a game guide, as I did after my first play-through, a couple of judicious saves and liberal use of the Skip" button will let you play quickly to the other ending and give you the couple of scenes you missed by choosing this restaurant instead of that one
date: and so forth.  Acing one or two of these alternatives unlocks extras that will let you look at the pictures of your times with Makoto and Akira
hoursPlayed: and give you an index of information about the sites you visited - you can also click through in-game to Googlemaps pictures of the places you go.\n\nThe game definitely wants you to end up with one sister rather than the other

reviewText:
Go Go Nippon! features cute girls giving you a tour and history lesson on things to do your first time in Japan.

+ Very informative, and would be extremely helpful for someone looking to travel abroad
+ Cute characters
+ Interesting currency mechanic
- Terribly ugly UI
- Stilted, awkward dialog between characters
- Exclamation marks used like a 15 year olds first fanfiction
- Ending was disappointing
- $10 for roughly 2-4 hours of content your first playthrough

If you were expecting something like Katawa Shoujo (admittedly like I was), do NOT buy this game. If you're looking to make a trip to Japan, it might be worth your while (but not for $10).

Do I recommend: Yes. For what it is, it does a pretty good job.Regardless of the pointless confession at the end of the game, it has the potential for a promising sequel.

reviewText:
If you've always been interested in playing a VN, this here is a good place to start.
You don't have many choices to make and there are no 'bad endings', but it shows you exactly what a VN is and how it plays like. It has no H-scenes, if that was what kept you from trying VNs in the past.

And if you enjoyed playing 'Go! Go! Nippon!' you can try other VNs, maybe even ones with H-scenes. (e.g. Shuffle, Wanko to Kurasou or Maji de Watashi ni Koi Shinasai! (only partial translated as of writing this))

reviewText: Decent visual novel that combines anime girls with some facts about Japan. I actually learned a thing or two - about toilets, train tickets and the history of Yokohama! It's neither super-serious (the main character seems... enthusiastic about pretty much everything that the superhumans of the glorious nation of Japan have so much as touched) nor does it avoid any of the tropes you would associate with a title like this: meaning awkward peeping-tom moments as well as general love-drama.\n\nThe art is nice, the writing is good (for this kind of thing) and it was entertaining while it lasted. Definitely one of the less embarassing titles of this sort to own on Steam and worth it if you actually want to learn some random history about Japan or study japanese (you can display dialogue both in english and japanese - which might be helpful).

reviewText:
It'd be easy to just dismiss Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ as a simple fanservicey VN for weeaboos, otakus and the like. Then again, it'd be easy to call Andrei Tarkovsky's Stalker little more than a cheap attempt at being 'deep' and 'meaningful'. Bottomline is that it's easy to call brilliant works of art like those bad simply because we cannot understand them when we first experience them. And experience is the right word to use here, oh yes.
Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ is a brilliant satire on otaku culture, a deconstruction of the stereotypes we slowly have accepted as the standard for the once great Japanese animation industry. I'd call it the Me!Me!Me! of visual novels, but that would be a slight insult to Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ because it's so damn amazing.
The game tells the story of a young man, the 'protagonist' who goes to Japan and, unsurprisingly, spends the week there with two attractive anime girls, Makoto, the stereotypical 'kind' girl with a giant chest compensated by her lack of personality, and Akira, who is more boyish and is almost flat chested. Note how the game right from the beginning comments on the 'blank slate' protagonist who serves as little more than an empty canvas for us to project our own personalities onto. This is the first in a long series of intelligent and cleverly constructed criticisms on otaku culture stereotypes: girls that are fairly skinny yet somehow still manage to have breasts larger than their own skull, how it's okay to sexualize young looking girls because 'they really are 18' or 'they aren't real so it's not paedophilia'. But never does the game do this too blatantly, like, say, Spec Ops The Line's criticism on the glorification of game violence and justifying violent actions in the name of good. No, each time the game brings up a valid point on one of the many subjects it touches upon it does so in a stylish, respectful and aesthetically refined way.
From here on, the review shall contain spoilers, so I'd recommend you to stop reading and play this masterpiece before you continue reading.
The story ends with the protagonist having learned that there's more to Japan than his so-called 'waifus' and eating sushi: in order to get the best ending, you have to try things you wouldn't necessarily associate with Japan (eating 'pizza' instead of sushi, which makes for a funny and charming moment when you and Akira begin to talk about how Japan has dealt with cultural influences throughout history) or give certain things you wouldn't expect an otaku to do a chance, like going for a nice morning jog (with one of the girls, as you'd learn later on) or eating a nice fruit salad Akira made for everyone in the house instead of emptying a bag of Doritos™ with some Mountain Dew™. Finally, you return home without having had anything 'sexual' with Akira and decide that she's worth a second visit to the country. You meet up again as you hold her tightly, having finally let go of your 2D chinese cartoon ladies and katana collection.
Finally, you can move on with your life, get a job, move out, meet a nice girl, maybe even start a family. We see the protagonist who now seems to be in his thirties shutting off his PC and going outside, where his two kids are playing together in the grass. He feels a soft touch on his shoulder and sees his wife smiling at him as she nods at your two children playing in the garden. You smile and close your eyes, holding your wife as you feel a warm summerevening's wind blowing against your face, and you know that in the end, everything is going to be alright.
tl;dr for all of you uneducated plebs: Akira best girl ♥♥♥♥ you and your cowtitted ♥♥♥♥♥ Makoto♥♥♥♥

reviewText:
Firstly, note that this game does not serve as a complete guide to Japan. You are better off looking elsewhere if you are SERIOUS about knowing more about Japan.

This is a more comprehensive review. Otherwise, there's nothing stopping you from paying for the game and enjoying a glorious experience. Have fun~

This Visual Novel basically serves as a nice short tour around a few sightseeing spots in Tokyo (hint: and Kyoto) along with two knowledgable girls who volunteered to serve as your guide during your short stay there. Explore around Japan in 2D as you develop a closer relationship with your guides. Google Maps link included at each sightseeing spot. (heh)

Your cute tour guides will show you several aspects of Japanese culture and some common occurances, as well as also providing a pretty decent explanation over each location. Though you might not able to see much, it gives you a vague idea of what to expect if you were to go there yourself.

As a VN, it provides a basic experience, with decent graphics and a short yet sweet storyline. The replay value isn't very much at all. You probably only need to replay the whole game at most once to view all the locations. Decision making will come up during destination picks for the first three days and during occasions when you have to pick something to eat, but there isn't much options for you otherwise.

In short, you are buying this VN because:

1. You want to know abit more about Japan. (yay)
2. You get to be accompanied by two friendly cute anime girls. (yay)
3. You get to develop a closer relationship with them. (yay)

If you are concerned about questionable scenes, this VN has two of those that may raise eyebrows. They cannot be avoided, so please take note~

Well, if that's what you are looking for......I suggest you look elsewhere.

reviewText:
Warning! This review includes a lot of spoilers about the game, so if You're interested in playing it on Your own, then please do Yourself a favour and don't read this!

Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~... Is this the perfect game?

This game makes You think that You're a total ♥♥♥♥♥, which You may have been while dating a girl, so now You'll just see how bad You might have been.

First, this game is a total opposite to the things Your mother has taught You. You, as the main character, meet two persons in a weird chat room, take out all Your money and fly to Japan. You've always thought they were guys, but  surprise surprise , they're two cute girls. Who the heck would do that?! At least have a video call or something before You go to some country and live at their place... Anyway...let that be. You meet two girls who were really waiting for You and had prepared a lot of stuff, which is nice. But then You find out that one of the girls doesn't speak English. No, they didn't tell You their genders and even lied to You? Damn, bad luck. But hey hey, at least You can speak Japanese!
You arrive at their house and find out that their parents had left for two weeks, so You can spend Your week in Japan with the girls, all alone... ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)
As I already said, they have prepared some stuff to do. They take You to places, talk about their history and importance. Then there also were some encounters, which were fun...sometimes... For example, Akira wouldn't let You to go to adult manga department. Damn, this was my main reason to play this game! Anyway, she also reads Your mind sometimes and that's really disturbing. When You go out with Makoto, then she almost gets abused by a guy and later she sees You as her hero and true love. Heh, sadly it's only the virtual world...
This game has two ending solutions, either You will fall in love with Akira or Makoto. I found falling in love with Akira a bit more interesting as she gets mad easily.
Basically, she takes You to a Chinatown (And let's be honest, You're disappointed). You see that she's not feeling well and suggest her to go home. She instantly gets the wrong idea and says that You can visit the town on Your own. After she finds out that You followed her, she gets normal for a second again, but after You won't let her to go to a store she runs away and locks herself into her room. You're sad, really sad. So is she...AND SHE HAS EVERY F-WORD RIGHT TO BE SAD! Later Makoto gets home, impressed because she thought that You'd be away for a bit more. As Akira locked herself into her room she wants to cook a dinner and finds a fridge full of goodies. She knows what's in Aira's head but You, a tiny snail with no brains still don't get anything. After the hint she gives You, You find out that Akira is in love with You. She won't talk to You, no matter how hard You try. Then, when You're going to leave Japan, You leave her a letter with all of Your feelings. As You're going to go through the gate, Akira runs into You and starts talking in her terrible English which is really really really cute. Then You wake up in a plane and notice a paper bag in Your hand. You remember that Akira gave it to You and peek inside. There is a doll of You and letter that tells You to wait for her. I, myself was most grateful for the bag because You never know when You're going to puke in a plane. A year later You break the promise and won't wait for her. You go to visit her and bump into her near a store. She calls You a jerk but it all ends happily.

Second ending is that You go with Makoto, she tells You that You can buy luck" and reads it for You. She herself got good luck

reviewText: I learnt so much about Japan while playing this game, this is one worth buying, after playing this game and learning so much I have now decided that I am going to visit Japan myself and see how trully awesome it is, hopefully like what I saw in this game. This is a brilliant learning game about Japan, no puzzle solving, just casual click and the music is really calm and peaceful. I reccommend this game big time although I do wish it could of gone on a little longer so I could completely learn everything about Japan, but oh well I guess I'll just start a new game and visit the other places :) Overall I rate this game 8/10, its worth the money and fun! there is a few things you can decide to choose to do, it even has a sweet little love story if you like to see that, the only thing I don't like about this game is that I didn't get to visit all the places in one save, but oh well I'll learn for myself when I visit Tokoyo and other places in Japan sometime next year now! :D

BUT, after I got a little Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ in my life, all that has changed. I am now a rather successful multi-thousand dollar rapper (Cop my new mixtape, Ronnie Ron-just chillin.")

reviewText:
TL;DR - I swore to myself I wouldn't buy this game. My shame is worth $1 Humble Bundle + the cost of cards.

Actual review - Now in all seriousness this game is stupid, so stupid it's genuinely entertaining. Here you are on your first trip to Japan. I'm guessing our protagonist is from middle of no where Europe. Location, probably spent a good part of his childhood in his mom's basement playing games and watching anime. Therefore every single thing he sees when he gets to Japan is superawesome amazeballs. Also the absolute luckiest guy in the world to meet 2 online friends who happen to be teenage Japanese girls. Not only do said Japanese girls offer him a spot to stay but their parents are out of town and is TOTALLY cool with some random internet stranger from mom's basement staying in their house with said teenage daughters.

When your character isn't thinking naughty thoughts about the sisters he's being wowed by Japanese culture. Did you know that Japanese restaurants give you a glass of water before you order? So do most other countries restaurants. This isn't something exclusive to Japan. Our main character even thinks when a cute girl handing out tissues it's a sign that she's interested in him because he's seen it in anime. His naivety knows no bounds.

Also in Japan a woman's cheerfulness directly correlates with the size of her breasts. The upbeat sister has huge boobs and doesn't mind when you accidentally walk in on her naked. The small boob sister seemed to have a chip on her shoulder for a good part of the game. But every VN needs a tsundere female to show tension or some junk.

Anyways there is a little bit of information about Japan in there. Nothing you couldn't find doing 10mins of research on the internet. But yeah, this game was so awkward I found myself just laughing during most of it.

reviewText:
I had rather mixed feelings on this game, in the end I had fun playing through a good chunk of it (visiting each city and learning something about them :) .)

The graphics are decent and don't differ too much from most visual novels on Steam. Music is also pretty decent (soundtrack DLC would be nice, hint hint.)

However, my only issue here is you're playing as a guy (I don't hate guys though) and it kind of saddens me because I would really like to be able to play this same game but from a woman's view (Akira and Makoto can stick, I don't see a huge issue there, would be friends rather than seeing them both compete for affection, unless they are bi, :P .)

In the end, I would not mind recommending this game, the only problem I had was you play as a guy (as per usual in almost every visual novel on Steam, very few exceptions.) Being able to visit each city and learn a little was pretty nice.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Go! Go! Nippon! is a light-hearted approach to Japan for beginners with a lot of interesting data combined with traditional Visual Novel (VN) style of narrative. Yes, it won't replace your Lonely Planet guide to Japan but it's still considerably fun, albeit some blatant pandering here and there.

Not much else can be said, you can input the current yen value for more accurate display of prices although I guess it doesn't contemplate the recent goods tax increase. Still, I'm not going to sit and talk about economics, that's what World End Economica is for! (Go check that too.)

But, yeah, I guess this is the tale of your average otaku/nerd living the dream with waifus mixed in the combo. Special note to the music, it's quite well done and the art is very pleasing to the eyes, as it's the case with most VNs. (Dat kawaii moe uguu thing.)

Special mention to the double language display. It's great for learning purposes!

reviewText: I give this a highly-conditional thumbs-up.  This is not a 'game' as such.  There are no game mechanics in play.  What this IS, is a tourist's introduction to Tokyo, with some anime-style story-fluff built around it.  There are no meaningful choices to be made, just picking what order you do things in.  The rest of your time will be spent reading.  It could just as easily have been made into a TV spot, and you wouldn't have to click as much.\n\nThat said, the art is decent, the summaries of various districts are made relatable, and I had fun learning things.  So I'm recommending it.  It's one of the better edutainment products I've tried and worth the five bucks in prep-work for an upcoming overseas trip.  But.. if you can't stand the typical socially-inept protagonists from damn near every anime comedy ever, maybe just visit a tourism website.

reviewText:
If you are looking for a game with in-depth story line and so many fun choices you have no idea what to do with yourself, this game is not for you.

This game is cute, to be sure - Makoto and Akira both have very different personalities and specialties.

But for me, this game falls short in alot of areas - LOTS of text about Japanese history. This isn't a bad thing; in fact, it was very informative and I enjoyed learning some things I didn't know about Japan. But sometimes I don't feel like reading a wall of text about this building or temple that was built 800 years about and the details of the Bakufu government back in the day.

The only choices that really make a difference are the places you want to visit the first three days you're there. The other few choices you get are only about food and don't affect anything at all.

This game was also incredibly short, with only two choices - I knew this going in, but I assumed that if there were only going to be two choices, then maybe the storyline would be more... in depth, more drama, more this and that.

I enjoyed this game for the few, few hours I played it, and the art was cute and I enjoyed reading the Japanese text along with the English text. But I would also say that I wouldn't pay the full $10. I got it for under $5 during a sale. But if cute girls informing you about Japanese history is your kink, buy this game immediately!

reviewText: Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ is a manga adventure set in the magical land of Japan. You play the role of a noble otaku who found two people from Japan to chat with over the internet, and as is the custom of Japanese people, they invited you into their home for a week while you visit Japan. When you arrive, your helpless little weeaboo of a man is marveled at just about everything in glorious Nippon, but quickly finds out that his hosts, Makoto and Akira are actually two young girls.\n\nFull Video Review and Playthrough here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fksXAXk0WAE

reviewText:
A cliched, cheap cash in on the whole Visual Novel genre.

The game does not have one bit of an original idea, and relies on already established tropes. It constantly reuses the same sky image for everything, be it a store or a building, because of pure lazyness to draw it, or even use a filtered photo for the subject of dialogues. Heck, even full conversations are played out with just one single image from time to time.

The fact that the MC is a complete ♥♥♥♥♥ doesn't help either. He supposedly had the life long dream of visiting japan, yet clearly knows NOTHING about it. Every time, he's avestruck by every damn thing, which gets really old, really fast. It's not like there's some super secret information revealed, but generic, every day life facts.

Seriously, who was this game geared towards? People who want to visit japan? I doubt, as they'd find the information contained in this game lackluster. Then how about people unfamiliar with japan? Well, why would they even care about this lol.

Whoever playtested this was drunk on sake.

reviewText: Even from the preview I saw, I knew I would love this game, and was extremely excited for it (which I haven't been THAT excited for a game in a long time). Bascially, if you want to know some stuff about Japan, and want to be taught about it by some cute girls that you can forge a relationship with, then this is right up your alley!\n\nYou play the role of a guy who's trying to learn Japanese, so he decided to go to Japan to be mentored by two brothers he met in an internet chat room. But, lo-&-behold, these two guys were actually sisters! You get to pick 3 of 6 places to take tours around before your time in Japan is up. Now, if you wanted to just learn about Japan, this is awesome enough as it is. BUT. Depending on which places you choose to tour, you develop a relationship with one of the two girls! TOO MUCH AWESOME. Not to mention, the endings are simply adorable. If you're someone like me who enjoys cute and innocent romances like Ai Yori Aoshi" or "Clannad
date:
I can just about guarantee you'll fall in love with this game! ...And one of the two girls! ;D

The soundtrack is amazing (I would have the game on in the background just to listen to the tunes), the visuals are great, and if you're actually trying to learn Japanese, it's great because in the dialogue, you can view the Japanese right above the English! The info they give you is fantastic, and the romance storylines are really nice!

All in all, I highly recommend this game! I sure had a blast playing it, and now I kind of want to learn Japanese so I can play through it while reading the top text. Not only that, I also have the goal of going to Japan in real-life to get firsthand experience. This game is a great way to get introduced to a new culture, and I surely hope they expand on this game in the future! Maybe a sequel or add-ons...? I hope so!
helpfulPercent: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A nice written japanese novel game!

The two female characters may be stereotypical at the base, but especially Akira shows a deep and lovely drawn character as the player progresses in the game. Only the player's character is drawn poorly, making it very hard at some points not wishing to punsh him in the face :D Nevertheless he also has his bright moments working well with the character progresses of Makoto and Akira.

The locations are well chosen and drawn. Even if the game itself is more like a digital comic (only few interactive parts) the little options to choose from and the two different endings bring up a nice replayability lacking in similar games like Sakura Spirit. On the top the player gets some nice and interesting facts about Japan's history, its locations around Tokyo and some cultural facts. Also some japanese phrases can be learned while playing.

Long story short: Whoever likes these kind of japanese graphical novel games or is interested in japanese culture should try this beautiful game. Unlike Sakura Spirit the focus on boobs and nudity is - beside two scenes - between very low and zero, serving the game's heart-warming dating part very well.

Buy. install and enjoy this short digital trip to Japan. But don't wonder if you want to go there in real life afterwards ;)

reviewText:
Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ is the first Visual Novel I tried here on Steam and I really liked it because not only it tells you a good story but it also allows you to learn interesting facts about Japan and its culture.

You will play as a boy making his first trip to Japan (Yeah, really !) and you will meet Makoto and Akira, two cute sisters who will be your guides during the full week. You will visit multiple places across the country (Though most of them are close to Tokyo) thanks to the really nice drawings and as the adventure evolves, you will eventually fall in love with one of them.

I would recommend this game if you want a brief glimpse of how amazing Japan is, stuck between tradition and modernity and if you like simple love stories. But you should go away if all you want is to do research because you will have nothing to see here.

My next step will be to come back later for the 2015 version. Also, I'm sorry Akira lovers but... Makoto <3 !

reviewText:
Okay, after playing it for few hours..I think I almost experience all the features inside this VN

Let's start with pros:
- It give you some knowledge about Japan + History
- Contain some converter feature so u can see how much you pay in USD or EU currency (need to insert exchange rate 1st at the beginning)
- Have some decent slice of life story
- The character design not bad
- They have quite good bgm and sound effect
- They add some button that make u can go inside browser to see real thing on like go'gle Street map (need internet connection)
- Ability to choose the destination

Now the Cons :
- No voice over, which make me feel lack somehow
- Lack of BG when inside some building or when event happened (Example :on event when they go inside convenience store. But the player just see the sky..)

although the cons just those 2 but it pack quite a punch

So I will rate it~
7/10

a Decent VN.

Note : They add some DLC in 2015 to make improve Go! go! Nippon, I think that means add lots of bg images to fix the cons and make the character with e-mote.

reviewText: Go Go Nippon is a virtual novel basically introducing a self-insert male character to Japan in a tourist environment. The artwork is quite good, but the dialogue is a bit... clunky at times (The main character is surprised that there are 24 hour convenience stores in Japan. Where in America does he come from that doesn't have those?). The background noise and music are good and the mechanics of the game such as the save/load system are reasonable. One particularly good point is the ability to look at a chat log of the recent dialogue in case you miss something. I got the game as a part of a bundle, so for me it was a good enough experience, but it's price is too high for it's tutorial-like feel and moderate length. If I had to choose three keywords for this game and the experience it gives, they would be awkward"

and "cute". The ending is particularly well done.
