reviewText:
Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/go-go-nippon-my-first-trip-to-japan-game-review/

Hey, look! A VN on Steam! Although a rare sight, it's always a welcome one. Especially considering that this is from MangaGamer, their first game on Steam. Props to them for bringing the title to Steam, hope to see more in the future.

Anyways, Go! Go! Nippon! is a semi-educational VN in which two beautiful girls give you a tour of some of Japan's popular sightseeing spots. A lot of the game is about Japanese history, with the other half being the development of a relationship with either of the two girls giving you the tour. I know little about Japanese history (I do, however, know a lot about its culture), making this game quite the enlightening experience. Now if only I could get the rest of my education taught through this format...

Aside from the game's educational aspect, there's also the relationship aspect. It may not be as large of an aspect as I had wanted, but it was enough for me to sit through the game's lecturing. The game opens with the protagonist landing in Japan and meeting up with two friends he had met online. Unknown to him, both friends are girls. Sisters, actually, who you'll be staying with for the duration of your visit. Coincidentally, their parents are gone on some trip and won't be back until your stay is over, one week.

You'll end up building a relationship with one of them, depending on the locations you choose to visit while staying in Japan. That aspect was a bit annoying, as I didn't know which of the two I'd be spending more time with. You're given no info about which girl corresponds to each location. I ended up going down a route I did not particularly want to. Well, that just adds to the replayability of the game, right? I'd say that 99% of VNs are developed with replayability in mind, as is Go! Go! Nippon! Playing through the game multiple times finally netted me the result I had wanted.

The game's art is fantastic. The characters and backdrops are great. There was no voice acting, which was a bit disappointing at first. Even if it was in Japanese (which I was originally expecting), I'd still prefer for it to be added. Instead, all dialogue is shown in both Japanese and English, which was quite cool. I've never seen a VN do that before. The game's music sounded rather generic, like it had been recycled from elsewhere. That said, I'd still like a soundtrack download, even if the tracks are recycled.

Overall, I can highly recommend Go! Go! Nippon! I'd love to see more VNs on Steam, especially some of those already available from MangaGamer (Shuffle! anyone?). Maybe we'll see more MangaGamer titles in the future. I'd personally love to see Shuffle! and its sequels, although I'm certain that Steam wouldn't allow it. :(

Anyways, be sure to check out the game. Give it a few plays for the full experience, one well had!

reviewText:
6.5 / 10.  Depends:
If it's on sale and you're planning a trip to Japan --- Recommend, but be ready to stifle gag reflex at lots of the dialogue
If you're seeking an engaging gaming (or fapping) experience --- Do not recommend


For those who enjoy visual novels and super-cheesy awkward text.  Very nerdy love story meets tour guide.  Comes with a budget (subway, entry fares, and conversion to Yen) but does not include alcohol or cover costs, and you somehow only eat out 3 times on a week-long vacation, so it's orders of magnitude off.  But tour factor of Tokyo, Hoshinka, Osaka, and a few surrounding areas is not bad; shows a variety of attractions (social, cultural, historical) with a brief placard-style dialogue about each one.

Requires two playthroughs to see all 6 attractions--which btw is how you pick" the girl you like.  Each girl shows 3 sites...the girl who shows you more
date: is who you "choose" --- however the game does not indicate which girl shows which site.  But no matter which ones you choose
recommended: on two playthroughs you will see the ending of both girls
hoursPlayed: as long as you don't repeat.  One of the love stories I will grudgingly admit is cute.\n\n"Two cute Japanese girls whose parents are away for the week" may sound like the start of a porno...but if you're expecting that
voteText: prepare for disappointment.  There are literally two still-shots with very minor states of undress (seriously 5 seconds on even the tamest hentai site would yield far more rewarding results there). Okay
helpfulPercent: so maybe you crave a classier approach involving no tentacles...but they don't wear anything remotely skimpy and do not change clothes EVER.  Both of them have only 3 body/facial expressions for any dialogue scenes (so
votesHelpful: almost the entire game).\nTL/DR: If you've seen the six steam screenshots
votesTotal: you've seen almost as much of the girls as you will in the ~3 hours of content (depending on reading time).\n\nBought it on sale as I'm planning on visiting Japan this year and definitely did find a few gems that I now want to see.  So from that perspective (and on sale) it was a win."

reviewText:
Bought this to practice my Japanese reading (I can read all hiragana and katakana and a few Kanji, mainly JLPT N5 level), as it has the Japanese text above the English. I get the bonus of learning information related to Japan at the same time. There's a lot of Kanji that I don't know though, so I keep having to go back and forth between Google translate to learn their readings. It would be much faster if Furigana was included, as at the moment I have to manually draw each unknown Kanji into the translator and then select it from a list.

However, the wide variety of kanji used will definitely help me learn faster.

So, if the developers read this, I'd greatly appreciate if you added in Furigana as an option :)

Edit: after searching the discussions board, it sounds like although Furigana won't ever be added, the DLC has a Romaji option. Well, that's better than nothing.

reviewText:
Pixel Judge review - http://pixeljudge.com/en/reviews/go-go-nippon-my-first-trip-to-japan/

The Verdict

When all is said and done, Go! Go! Nippon does its job admirably. It could have benefited from some better scripting, and greatly benefited from some better interactions (by the developers) with people from the unnamed Western (America or somewhere in Europe) country the protagonist is supposed to hail from. But all in all, it does what it does in an efficient, generally interesting and occasionally quite touching way. It’s a decent attempt at enticing a new audience into the visual novel genre, but not one to really do anything unique.

3.5/5

reviewText:
I really love this game for its realism. It demonstrates the possible objects and facts you may engage during your 1st time visiting Japan (well, if you haven’t got much acknowledge of them). For example, you may stand in front of a vending machine for some time trying to figure out why not only it serves drinks but also sells bunches of snacks you’ve never seen before and packs of all kinds of cigarettes. Seriously? And putting too much Wasabi in your plate and eat them altogether is dangerous, because it will get you and your food both killed. Okay! And take an extra caution before travelling alone to the famous Tokyo station in order to avoid constantly getting lost and failed to catch your train. Get lost in a train station? What a hell? Are you certain? Hey! Wait a minute!

My boyfriend has his prospective of the game wrote below.

Hi, guys! As Japanese myself I am pretty amazed by how detailed the information has been structured in this game. It pretty much covered majority of the stuff you may interact and may later be interested in Japan. Thus it’s a pretty convinced example of guiding people along the way before them literally coming over to it and suddenly experiencing the unpleasant “Culture Shock”. The game is honestly a good tour, far better than the most of the tour-guide books you can easily grab in a book shop. If you would like to visit Japan some times, and wondering what it looks like. I would recommend you play this game, even just for a manga version of its prospective. It’s fun and relaxing.

And of course, my girlfriend wrote it above based on her experience as a foreigner, is realistic, and moreover, true to her heart.

Scarlet's Score: 8.3/10
Ken's Score: 8.5/10

reviewText: If you are into visual novels with lots character development and character interaction that leaves an impact than this game is not really for you. But in retro-spect if you are planning on going to japan and are a male (wink wink, nudge nudge) then this will help you with things to do around the Tokyo region and Kyoto region with a slight romance story to break up all the travel facts and Japanese history. i would recomend this to people who are interested in traveling to Japan for a short period of time but not to people who are into highly thought out and developed visual novels unless you want something quick and easy to follow with only slight emersion. I'd give it about a 6 out of 10 because the romance aspect had some fairly well thought out moments and it gave me a good insite into sight seening in Tokyo and the regions around it.

reviewText: Was short but I thoroughly enjoyed it. You actually do learn things about japan along the way and you get two cute characters to lead you along the way. It takes a while for the relationship of the main character and the girls to blossom but other than that I enjoyed the personality contrasts between the two sisters. Plus, there is replay value since you obviously don't get the ending of both girls at once. Also, you will not be able to visit every place on your first playthrough or possibly even your second. So there is potential for much more. It's a silly adventure and you just need to take it for what it is. I think I ended up beating this in 5 hours since I took my time through it. I will be playing through again to see the rest of the scenes. I recommend this game and I would take advantage of the deal going on until the 28th of february.

reviewText:
For all that hipsters and cynics love to mock it, we owe a lot to Go! Go! Nippon!. It was Monster Girl Quest 3 that set the benchmark for how visual kawaii novels looked and played in the HD era. It was Monster Girl Quest 2 that redefined the FPS as all-action blockbuster, while transforming PC single-player. So it’s a shame to report that Go! Go! Nippon! doesn’t set any new benchmarks or redefine anything. When OverDrive dropped Monster Girl Quest 3 to kick off a new series it could have given the franchise a brand new start. Instead we have something that’s less a reboot than a remake, giving us everything we expect from a Go! Go! Nippon! turned up to eleven, but nothing more.

The premise is interesting, albeit faintly ridiculous. In the near future a new power – The Toliet – rises the water from the bowl and swirls around.  Your character is shocked by the advancement that the Japanese aquired in their technology, For ten years your weeaboo habits have exceeded in a positive manner, allowing you a trip to Japan for quite some time. Aided by two girls who acompany you through your journeys. The single-player campaign charts the story of you showing up in Japan from a train, and after a short prolouge, are acompanied by two females. One with a large pair of brests that have obviously been over detailed to draw your eyes to, and a flat chested but unrealistic personality female.

In theory – and in OverDrive PR campaign – this sounds brilliant. You’re not fighting or doing anything interesting, but as a beta weeaboo who travels to Japan is hilarious. In practice, though, it’s all still business as usual, with access to the ladies, air support and high-tech gadgets, and missions covering all the usual infiltrate this, run to this point, visit this place tomfoolery.

What saves the game is its spectacle. OverDrive seems to have invested heavily in engine tech to make the scenery plants, intense sound effects, absolutely interesting dialouge and no level is complete without something big doing all of these things, often all at once when you’re running-and-gunning through it. When things aren’t getting wrecked, we get sudden erotica, This makes each mission like the climax of a blockbuster action movie, and while the effect is wearying spread out over the running time, it’s a great game to play one mission at a time. You know you’ve seen it all before, but you’ve never seen it quite this big.

reviewText: In this game, you play as a dummy weeaboo who gets to take a trip to Japan at the invitation of two people he met online whom, because of their dual gender names, he didn't know were both girls. The game consists of picking places to tour and having some awkward moments because anime stuff like walking in on people changing clothes happens. The information the game gives about Japan is pretty neat, though some of it might not still be current (I personally have no idea). And eventually, of course, it ends in a romance plot with the girl you spent the most time with. Hooray.\n\nAs generic and predictable as everything is, it's not necessarily bad either. It's a short little VN where you may learn a few things, which isn't exactly common. Go ahead and get this if you want to learn some novel things about Japan... or if you just want a short cheap game that gives you cards. XD

reviewText:
Strategy on a massive scale, conquering Japan, invading boobs , smashing Girls.  What's not to like?

Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan is fully complete game. But great fun, I have to say, and it's already starting to show that it will go where no RTS has gone before when it comes to gameplay.

As of January 2014, the real innovation is beginning to show, as Uber has started implementing important gameplay functionality. Area commands turn the task of managing whole planets into a breeze, while new units such as the stargate-like teleporter shows off how interesting solar system-wide warfare will be.

Yes, the current price is a bit steep, but this is basically an extension of the Kickstarter campaign, your money goes towards the development of the game, and you receive some bonuses in exchange along with immediate access to the game, and upon buying, you get the full game.

If you feel that youre interested in the game and would like to contribute towards the completion, I recommend going for it now.

Otherwise, the price will go lower once the final product launches, and if you prefer a polished experience rather than a rapidly changing finished version, I recommend holding off for a while.

In summary, if you loved Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander, but would like to take it a couple steps further, this is a game for you.

reviewText:
Go! Go! Nippon! was the first title that MangaGamer published on Steam, and me being a vivid VN player and Japanese Studies student, I instantly felt the need to get this game. At first, this seemed like a perfect start for Visual Novels to appear on Steam, especially after other titles like Analogue and its sequel, Hate Plus. But after going through all of it, I'm not sure whether this is worth your time.

This game feels more like a kinetic visual novel, with choices that don't really make a difference. You can go through the whole story without saving a single time, but because of forced branching you'll have to go through it twice (blind choices however). Basically, the estimate as given by the VNDB is correct (2 to 10 hours). Is paying 10 dollars worth this gameplay time? Up to you to decide. The characters are quite stereotypical but on the other hand, you can enter your own name, which might be quite to your liking. I just wished that they also showed the Japanese price (instead of just your own currency) when buying something, since you most likely will be carrying only Japanese yen with you while you travel.

So why do I not recommend this game? Basically, I found it a bit too short for my liking (at least Europeans tend to travel for at least 2 weeks when going this far abroad), but there's something that was bugging me more. The translation quality. I found it very lacking and so did other friends of mine who are proficient at Japanese. I made several screenshots that show obvious grammatical mistakes that usually only beginners would make. Since this game is actually giving both the Japanese and the English text, it's supposed to be aimed for Japanese language learners (you would have no other reason otherwise), but this definitely backfires instead.

Another thing is that the game is already quite dated. While the game released on Steam this February, it was first released in September 2011. At one point of the story, they're talking about the Tokyo Skytree, which was yet to be opened on the time of the release, but it's one of the most popular tourist attractions nowadays. I also felt like they're not talking enough about the typical spots too. Not a single word about Tokyo Disneyland and Tokyo Disney Sea, and even the 109 building at the Shibuya Scramble Crossing. Kinkaku-ji was greatly praised, but no word of it's counterpart, Ginkaku-ji.

If you feel like you might go to Japan for the first time someday, with Tokyo as main destination, and love to have some nice fantasy about it beforehand, pick it up if you think it's worth the money. If you're already studying Japanese, chances are you know most of it already, and this will make you kind of annoyed at some times. The main protagonist is a know-all when it comes to Japanese, but is a complete blockhead when it comes to the culture. It's also feels incomplete, so if you want a great guide...Just buy an actual guidebook. Or else...Just find some Japanese tour guides in real life. It's not that hard if you look for backpacker or couchsurf sites out there.

reviewText:
Gomenasai, my name is Ken-Sama.

I’m a 27 year old American Otaku (Anime fan for you gaijins). I draw Anime and Manga on my tablet, and spend my days perfecting my art and playing superior Japanese games. (Disgaea, Final Fantasy, Persona series)

I train with my Katana every day, this superior weapon can cut clean through steel because it is folded over a thousand times, and is vastly superior to any other weapon on earth. I earned my sword license two years ago, and I have been getting better every day.

I speak Japanese fluently, both Kanji and the Osaka dialect, and I write fluently as well. I know everything about Japanese history and their bushido code, which I follow 100%

When I get my Japanese visa, I am moving to Tokyo to attend a prestigious High School to learn more about their magnificent culture. I hope I can become an animator for Studio Ghibli or a game designer!

I own several kimonos, which I wear around town. I want to get used to wearing them before I move to Japan, so I can fit in easier. I bow to my elders and seniors and speak Japanese as often as I can, but rarely does anyone manage to respond.

Wish me luck in Japan!

reviewText:
Are you interested in Japan or Japanese culture? Ever wanted to visit Tokyo? If so this might be a game for you.

You travel to Japan for a week and get to know the sites as explained by some local friends you met on the Internet. It's a glorified travel brochure in a way, but nicely presented, with a cheesy, though cute little story to tie it all together.
A particularly nice touch is that most locations have a button that takes you to a picture of the place you're visiting on Google Maps.

If you're looking for a deeper story, look elsewhere. The game is short and mostly there for interesting facts and trivia.

reviewText: This game is awesome, the characters in it are amazing, the story is interesting and you get to learn a lot of stuff about Japan. Even though I know quite a bit about the history and culture of Japan, I still learned a bit from it. One thing that really bothered me was that you play as a guy and that he's a bit of a numbskull. Due to the way the story goes It wasn't that much of a problem and without it might not have been as much fun. The other complaints I have about this game is that there are things he finds really special about Japan that are fairly common in the Netherlands. I don't know about other countries though. But I think that hot water from the tap is fairly normal, shops in train stations is quite common as well and I don't think 14 platforms at a station in Tokyo is all that much. I think that is quite a average amount for a train station in a large city.

- You get attacked by a toire
- Lots of ellipsis'
- Fall in love with a girl who can cook, but doesn't know English as well as the other, or a girl who can't cook at all (not that cooking matters, it's not like you actually eat it), with bigger body parts and knows English well
- You then realize in real life that this game was made for the love story and body parts rather than for touring Japan
- You also have to explain why you bought this to your friends, and possibly your parents
- You then keep playing the game for the sake of Japan.
- You realize that there are only two reasons people bought this. For the story"

reviewText: Definetly a sweet way to get to know Japan but without knowing the credibility of anything said I can't really judge the game for that. As for the Visual Novel aspect - the plot is pretty straight-forward for such a short title. Either go around more and end up with love interest 1 or 2 (Go! Go! Akira-chan!). The animation, or more like the lack of it, is bad. There are very few backgrounds and sprites and sometimes the scenery is just black which is awkward... Although I do admit that the pictures that the game DOES have are pretty nice. As for the nudity tag and age confirmation I can only laugh as the VN has none of it. Still the logo of Mangagamer is up front so this could be an all-age version of an eroge. Overall I enjoied the SUICA propaganda thrown at me and Akira's punches.\n\n7/10 would beat the tsun out from dere again.

reviewText:
This is a really WOW game. Its functions is pretty simple as it a dialog click and read along anime game. The game has 2 different endings. One with  in a relationship with Akira. The second ending is in a relationship with Makoto. Also when your at dfferent locations. There's another button under menu that actually opens up Google Maps in your browser. To see the real 3D images of what the locations are like in street view on Google Maps. Which I find a very novelty idea if your researching Japan as well.

SynopsisThe storyline is based on an exchange student visiting Japan to meet his fellow friends he met on the internet. That was meeting him at the airport when he arrives. Then he meets them in person and is shocked or surprised to find that his online friends was actually girls and not guys.

After travelling to the girls home. They fully get to know each other. With some misunderstanding incidents and unepecting moments occuring in the story.

Akira and Makoto the next couple of days shows you around different places in Japan.

reviewText: Go! Go! Nippon! is a short visual novel most likely intended to be more educational or at least to lend a somewhat idealised insight of a trip to Japan rather than to be a standalone story. The cast is downright minimal, CG usage sparse and quality of the writing quite basic. However, as much as its possible to reprimand its simplicity it can just as much be a positive note -- it feels as though this would make a neat little My First VN".\n\nThe novelty of GGN! comes from its usage of a dual text box showing both English and original Japanese text. For anyone interested in learning or
recommended: someone who has a moderate knowledge of the language it makes a nice reference point. If I had any criticism of this it was that it wasn't possible to hide one or the other languages on the fly (to practice reading and translating) and there was no option to enable furigana for the more complex/rare kanji to really make it stand out as a learning aid. A full AGTH-like interface such as the ability to hover individual words/kanji and see more detailed information would have really made it useful for this
hoursPlayed: although this could have been achieved manually by playing with a dictionary in hand.\n\nThe protagonist is very much meant to be a self-insert for the player: someone who wishes to visit Japan and knows odd bits of the history and customs through anime as well as a bit of study; punctuated in moments where some of their expectations get shot down when reality has been stretched by the fiction they know. The only real sense of disbelief here is that while they claim to have done a "little bit of study" on the language
voteText: they speak damn near fluently save for plot
helpfulPercent: learning or surprise. The two girls of the game -- Makoto and Akira -- are very much cardboard cutouts of standard anime personalities: the knowledgeable and understanding older sister and the tsundere
votesHelpful: slightly tomboyish younger sister. As far as writing is concerned I cant really fault either of them as much as I cant really find much interesting or unique about them. Its almost clinical. The romance between either one of them feels rather contrived also. More dialog/choices during trips with them probably wouldve done well to blur this a bit.\n\nAnyone who has been to Japan may find themselves relating or reminiscing with the protagonist
votesTotal: their mindset and any revelations they encounter (the teeming trains and scarcity of ATMs being mine) but
votesFunny: as I say
commentsCount: this VN is most likely intended for people who havent had the opportunity to visit and are willing to play a short VN on the subject as a form of self-tortu-- motivation.\n\nTheres a number of VNs out there I can and would recommend to people not interested in Japan
column16: anime or even the culture at all but (and this probably goes without saying) this is not one of them. It feels a cop-out to end a review like this
column17: but if you even think youll like this game then you likely will. GGN! is very much a game built for people who would be interested in the first place. Theres no hidden gems here
column18: just a VN thats so on the nose you may as well call it Pinocchio."

reviewText:
A great way to learn more about Tokyo!

Gameplay:
This game has some amazing art and a story that lets you chose between two beautiful girls. During the game you get to chose to which location of Tokyo you want to go and learn a lot about that location. Because of this you get to know allot about the different zones of Tokyo and what they have to offer. It also gives you a link to google maps where you can see the location where you are in the game. What is also very useful is that you get to learn a few facts about traveling by train in japan.

The Story:
The game has a enjoyable story (not very long but quite eventful). It is the protagonists first time in Japan and he gets to stay with two really cute girls! During his time with them he learns a lot about Tokyo and becomes really close with them. But what he learns and with whom he becomes the closets is something you can best discover by playing the game...

A  fun  visual novel with likeable characters.
I truly recommend giving it a shot if you havent already!

reviewText: I think this game was designed as an enty-level weeb VN, but is a horrible attempt at anything like that. It has the pretence of being a infomational game all bout Japan, and gives you countless completely useless facts like specific oyster card savailable for the underground train system of inner Tokyo. All facts will be forgotten in a few minutes, guaranteed, tbqh I wouldn't even recommend trying to remember them. The two girls who show you Japan" consist of a tsundere and a nee-san character archetypes. While not being particularly exciting anyway

recommended: and then she'll suddenly switch to robot mode and start listing different ♥♥♥♥ing post office branches you can find arounf Tokyo.\n\nI think the reason most people will buy this is because they want to get into the world of VNs. If that is the case go elsewhere

reviewText:
Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan is a half tourist, half romantic visual novel. You will discover Japan with 2 girls- Akira and Makoto. There are in total 6 places to visit, you can visit 3 of them in 1 playthrough, and the ending will be depending on you choices of location, there are in total 2 endings, so a ending per girl. I found the ending with Makoto more romantic while the other ending with Akira is a little more tragic, but both endings ends in a happy way, no bad endings.

This VN helps quite a lot for those who wants to travel to Japan. It gives some basic informations on 6 sightseeing albums (the names can be found in the game or in the strategy guides)  tourist attractions, and the good thing is, you can even enjoy a love story while discovering Japan. I found this visual novel quite fantastic and different from the others, it's worth to give it a try.

Positive remarks
+graphics
+2 endings
+additional information on Japan, can be a nice tour guide
+storyline
+actually appropriate for all ages
+soundtracks are nice

Negative remarks
-(maybe to me only) the ending of Akira isn't very interesting
-sometimes, reading or listening to the girls about Japan can be boring
-cannot be played a lot of times

reviewText:
First of all despite the tags, and reviews stating otherwise, this game does not have nudity at least not the nudity you would be thinking of with that tag, or with what other reviews mention, all the nice parts are covered. There is also NO SEX (H-scenes) at ALL, don't be mislead! If you want boobies and sex in your game, The Witcher series is a great first start. Snowdrop is also good choice.

This game truely falls into the Visual Novel category, those looking for more interaction" or choices that affect the outcome are going to be very disappointed. The lack of voice acting also put a damper on the experince. Its basically a well illustrated "E-book"

That being said this game does exactly what it says it would do
date: give you a "guided tour" of certain parts in Japan. However I must throw in that just a quick look on google will get you more images of the sites mentioned in this game. They could have done much more
recommended: there are many scenes in the game where you are looking at clouds
hoursPlayed: when they could be showing you just what is being talked about
voteText: or what is happening.\n\nThe "love sim" aspect is basically non existant and seems rather thrown on at the end. Those looking for something along the lines of "Snowdrop"(which is the only love sim I have really played) will also be disappointed. I am still not sure how you can chose a specific partner
helpfulPercent: I guess its the tourist destinations you chose that have an impact. To its credit the endings do pull at your heart strings
votesHelpful: slightly but it does evoke some form of reaction
votesTotal: I doubt anyone is going to burst into tears (happy or sad) at the ends.\n\nI would give this game an 7.5/10 rating
votesFunny: it does what its meant to do and does it well
commentsCount: however its rather limited choices for player and interaction in general limit its replayability. I am certainly pleased with my purchase of this game but it could have done more than what it did
column16: there was a lot of missed potential here but at its current price I cannot complain. If it was any higher my "score" would drop quite a bit."

If you're going to get the game in hopes of a romance between you and those girls, it won't be all that satisfying to be honest. As the About This Game" section says: "a guidebook in game format!"

Playing through this game brought a lot of nostalgia of my times in Japan. Some information is outdated
date: like the SUICA and PASMO cards (there's an app for both!)

reviewText:
Go! Go! Nippon! is a visual novel about a guy from an ambiguous country that takes a sightseeing tour around Japan (mostly Tokyo) with the help of two Japanese girls. This game is a bit of an oddity. There's actually very little gameplay here; you make roughly five choices throughout the whole experience.

Most of this novel consists of an animated, factual tour guide of Japanese hot spots, complete with history lessons. I found it pretty interesting, if a little dry at times. It was pretty neat to see Shibuya, which I remember from two other games I've played (The World Ends With You and SMT: Devil Survivor). This game tries really hard to capture the feel of everyday events in Tokyo, and it was cool to see all of these things described in great detail and in a way that points out things that foreigners would find unique.

You might also expect some romance from this description, and if so, you'd be correct. The places you visit determine which girl accompanies you, and you end up with the one that accompanied you the most. I only played through once, and I saw a little over half the content. The romance plot is not that interesting and ends before it really blooms. I kind of wish it was left out, especially the more, well, risque images. (Ecchi, I think. Not quite hentai.)

So basically, if you're looking for a fun game, this isn't one. This is a visual novel about being a tourist in Japan stapled to a romantic manga story. It only took me about 90 minutes to get through one playthrough, so it's a pretty quick experience. All in all, if you can enjoy a visual novel and you have some interest in Japan, I can recommend this. Not at $10, though... wait for a Steam sale. If my description didn't sound interesting to you, then this simply isn't for you and it won't be worth your time or money.

reviewText:
I can't believe I didn't write a review for this when I first played it. I love this visual novel. It teaches you about a lot of cool locations and aspects of Japan. Quite frankly you could experience culture shock just by playing this. If you want a laid back VN that's actually full of really cool trivia and facts about Japan, you should definitely pick this up.

However, if you do pick it up, I recommend getting it with the 2015 DLC. That DLC improves the game tenfold in pretty much all areas while also doubling the content. I went from 6 hours to 15 hours (and still going) because I want to do multiple playthroughs. This allows me to visit all of the locations, discover all of the CG, and read all of the dialogue. The 2015 DLC is pretty much the Brave New World of Civilization, so it's definitely really recommended to get.

There are a couple slight and brief NSFW factors to this game. They only last like, five seconds each and there's two sections where it'll happen. Just make sure you're not playing with someone in the room! (once you get the second one, though, you're in the clear.)

There are some other little details behind this game but I think they should be discovered as you go in.

Remember, this is a visual novel, if you don't like reading and looking at pictures then don't bother. It's really silly when people buy a visual novel and go Wtf? This isn't a game!""

reviewText:
As a fan of visual novels and someone with a mild interest in Japanese culture, I was intrigued by the idea of a guidebook to Japan that could be experienced in a video game format. I bought Go! Go! Nippon! as part of a bundle and was eager to try it out in hopes of seeing a unique mix of story, characters, and culture. Unfortunately, I was disappointed.

The characters were shallow and unneccesarily awkward, with juvenile writing and dialogue that seemed like it was built for an almost illiterate teenage audience. The plot (outside of sightseeing in Japan) was nonexistent. The only decisions the player gets to make revolve around which sights to go see and the relationship aspect of the game seems contrived and more than a little bit forced.

If you're looking for something to give you a hint of Japan's culture you might enjoy this. (I definitely learned a couple of things about Japan that I didn't know, despite only playing for around thirty minutes.) If you're looking for a more in depth experience than a Wikipedia page with a smiling anime girl on it, though, look eslewhere.

reviewText:
I got this in a Groupee bundle so the cost i paid for this game is about 70 - 72 = -2 cents, 72 cents gained from selling the 4 steam cards, so its a 2 cents profit.

There's 2 seperate endings which depends on how much time u spend with each girl in the first 3 days. The most interesting fact (to me) I learned about Japan is that in Yokohama, they have like a mausoleum for Guan Yu, a revered Three Kingdoms general (who totally never had any contact with Japan), which shows that Japanese had such deep respect for Romance Of The Three Kingdoms, as can be seen from the games they made

Pros:
+ Dialogue is quite funny at times
+ Trains u to read faster, it will
+ If u are learning Japanese, this is useful
+ Nice music
+ General knowledge about Japan & culture

Cons:
- Not many choices, its linear
- Background artwork are blurry sometimes

Conclusion:
Its my first time playing a visual novel, but the main reason i do this is to find out more about Japan. Both the characters are likeable. I am paid 2 cents to enjoy my experience, instead of having to pay $2000 to go Japan, so why not? Just my two cents

reviewText:
I haven't seen any dialogue choices plus art seems a bit poor ( anatomy, backgrounds ). On top of that fan service... really unnecessary. Totally put me off from finishing this game. Instead of keeping it clean and cute... This game should have a warning about age restrictions.

Even though you visit some of the places there aren't many pictures you can see... lack of backgrounds makes this rather shallow travel experience. Not recommended at all.

If you are looking for a good story and that Visual Novel experience with multiple endings... well look somewhere else. This one could have been done better but instead it is just a gimmick... plus if you are interested in Japan you would have already known lots of the information given in this VN.

reviewText:
The title alone should hint that this isn't really a game, just a tourist brochure that tried to have an entertaining framework.

When compared to most Visual Novels, it has a lousy plot and does not flesh out the characters.  There's a long list of free VNs that boast great characterization and a deeper plot, and they even lack the perverted bits!

If you're a fan of Visual Novels, go buy Hate Plus or Analogue instead.  If you're a fan of Japanese Visual Novels (as opposed to Original English ones like this one), you'll be disappointed even further.

If you're looking for things to satiate your unspeakable desires, then this VN will also disappoint, I guarantee it.

Recommended audience:  the kind of people who REALLY want to go to Japan but have the funds for fork over $10, and can thus go to an art gallery featuring drawings of Japanese locales without the actual experience of being there.

reviewText:
Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ is an unusual experiment that trades heavily on novelty but fails to leave a lasting impression.

The game presents itself as a tourist guidebook-esque visual novel intended for English-speaking audiences--this being rather alien territory for the genre--with all the trappings of the genre. Indeed, the attractive (albeit limited) art, interface and scenario design are rooted in the traditions of the Japanese visual novel. Unforunately, the experience is too brief and the informational aspect too slim; the game falls short of both of its propositions.

While the premise is intriguing, the characters are archetypal and the attempts at comedy and romance are tired and toneless. The main character--a foreigner homestaying with a pair of Japanese siblings--is merely a palette swap of the garden-variety protagonists found in lesser Japanese visual novels. His amorous leanings disappoint with their banal outcomes, and the girls fare no better. Makoto is a classical Japanese housewife-type whose prinicpal character flaw is an apparent inability to follow a recipe. Akira is a stand-offish, zesty younger sister whose conflicted romantic intentions toward the main character are too expected and textureless to muster any emotion in the player.

The game scenario branches into two storylines focusing on either girl, though the player receives no warning of how the limited choices to be made over the course of the game lead to which unaffecting outcome. The overall narrative has a distinct back-patting tone when mention is made of various technologies employed throughout Tokyo. The protagonist's constant amazement of Japanese technological progress and paradisiacal protrayal of Japanese life should strike any player familiar with the reality of living in Japan as disingenuous and irresponsible.

As a resource for would-be tourists, there is still more disappointment in store. The various guided tours of areas within Tokyo (and a few out-of-prefecture day trips) feel spartan and excessively-curated. Visits to points of interest within a given locale can be counted on one hand, and each day of the week's adventure ends before it seems to have begun. Wikipedia offers a more comprehensive study of the various neighborhoods of Tokyo than can be found in this game.

The game allows for currency conversions for all transactions in the game, ostensibly to fascilitate budgeting for a similar trip, but the usefulness of the feature is destroyed by how many costs are overlooked. That the protagonist lodges with a Japanese family--at no cost to him, one must presume--disregards one of the most significant expenses of a trip to Japan. Sadly, the greater preoccupation of the scenario writer was clearly the trite romantic comedy woven between the educational passages.

The music is servicable fare, limited to a handful of tunes that never become grating, if only due to the brevity of the game. Characters do not speak their lines, and aside from occasional sound effects, the background music is left to carry the scenes--a challenge far beyond its capacity.

A small offering of bonus features becomes availabe at the end of the first playthrough, though these provide little incentive to return to the shopworn storyline.

Fans of novelty and experimentation will find some redeeming qualities in what Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ has accomplished, but anyone looking for a captivating narrative or a useful resource for planning a stay in Japan would be better served by almost anything else.

reviewText:
Gave a mate Hatoful Boyfriend Collecters Edition for Christmas.
Got this in return.
Best game I've ever played by far.

After finding some Japanese friends on an online chat room, you decide to visit them in Japan. Quickly ignoring the fact the could be fat and forty pedos, you hop on aplane and discover they are in fact girls. You then have to spend a week with your token older and younger sister anime girls in Tokyo, luckily their parents are on a 'Buissiness trip' and they look after you. After donning some specialy made tour costumes, it's off into the streets with the girls that have a surprisingly large knowledge of theri city and who you can romance.

+ Amazing soundtrack
+ Educational game
+ Somewhat of a dating game
+ Nice art
+ Fastest flight ever
+ Really helpful video on homepage
+ Great experince to role play with mates on skype
+ Amazing gameplay

- Can't really tab out
- Anime cliches
- I don't speak foriegn
- Dunno yet, I should play more...

reviewText: Oh my gosh, the glorious, sweet Nippon. The Haijun to my Bushido, the Saki to my Hibi. This is absolutely the best game if you want to feel like you are really in Japan.  Being able to play this really made my Otaku nature just flow out as if I had actually been there. The hibiki around me was just as beautiful as the yuki. Makoto and Akira are the absolute loves of my life for sharing their home with me so that I could spend my week in Japan.\n\nIt's like my anime dreams come true, 10/10 would Japan again.

reviewText:
Ok, i'll keep this short for those who don't want to read.
Art - 6/10
Kinda dissapointing, just the same cycle of images over and over along with a small amount of facial expressions. Google maps link is nice and innovative. Food sketches are rather pleasing however. The girls are nothing special and just serve to be usual cardboard cutout sisters recycled over and over as Japan is known famously for, the sweet heart kudere and the yandere.

Writing - 5/10
Does a good job of explaining Japan and it's culture. However there are some typos and some English saying's thrown in that serve no purpose and just seem completely off e.g. That's totally metal". Don't come in expecting voice acting
date:
because there is non! Furthermore the usual tropes are here that anyone would expect. It seems that all eastern women think western men think of nothing but engaging in sexual acts with anything that has a pulse. The gags are also terribly cringy and poorly implemented.

Story - 5/10
Sets out be a organised trip of Japan but ends up being more like an interactive propaganda video for Japan which isn't a problem in itself but this odd love narrative they try to string in is. It's all completely out of place considering they only did it to draw in a more pervese audience and give you a reason just to struggle through days if talking about Japanese history isn't you thing.

Gameplay - 1/10
What do you expect? Interactive slideshow. But if you like VN's then this is up your street.

Feels - 8/10
Characters grew on me like wart.

Vodka's Overall Rank - 7/10
Would only recommend to hardcore VN's lovers. If you want a real idea about Japan
recommended: go on a guided tour. Or read a book. You won't have to deal with annoying sisters who leave their door open so you can see their ♥♥♥ then put salt in your coffee."

reviewText:
Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ is an unusual experiment that trades heavily on novelty but fails to leave a lasting impression.

The game presents itself as a tourist guidebook-esque visual novel intended for English-speaking audiences--this being rather alien territory for the genre--with all the trappings of the genre. Indeed, the attractive (albeit limited) art, interface and scenario design are rooted in the traditions of the Japanese visual novel. Unforunately, the experience is too brief and the informational aspect too slim; the game falls short of both of its propositions.

While the premise is intriguing, the characters are archetypal and the attempts at comedy and romance are tired and toneless. The main character--a foreigner homestaying with a pair of Japanese siblings--is merely a palette swap of the garden-variety protagonists found in lesser Japanese visual novels. His amorous leanings disappoint with their banal outcomes, and the girls fare no better. Makoto is a classical Japanese housewife-type whose prinicpal character flaw is an apparent inability to follow a recipe. Akira is a stand-offish, zesty younger sister whose conflicted romantic intentions toward the main character are too expected and textureless to muster any emotion in the player.

The game scenario branches into two storylines focusing on either girl, though the player receives no warning of how the limited choices to be made over the course of the game lead to which unaffecting outcome. The overall narrative has a distinct back-patting tone when mention is made of various technologies employed throughout Tokyo. The protagonist's constant amazement of Japanese technological progress and paradisiacal protrayal of Japanese life should strike any player familiar with the reality of living in Japan as disingenuous and irresponsible.

As a resource for would-be tourists, there is still more disappointment in store. The various guided tours of areas within Tokyo (and a few out-of-prefecture day trips) feel spartan and excessively-curated. Visits to points of interest within a given locale can be counted on one hand, and each day of the week's adventure ends before it seems to have begun. Wikipedia offers a more comprehensive study of the various neighborhoods of Tokyo than can be found in this game.

The game allows for currency conversions for all transactions in the game, ostensibly to fascilitate budgeting for a similar trip, but the usefulness of the feature is destroyed by how many costs are overlooked. That the protagonist lodges with a Japanese family--at no cost to him, one must presume--disregards one of the most significant expenses of a trip to Japan. Sadly, the greater preoccupation of the scenario writer was clearly the trite romantic comedy woven between the educational passages.

The music is servicable fare, limited to a handful of tunes that never become grating, if only due to the brevity of the game. Characters do not speak their lines, and aside from occasional sound effects, the background music is left to carry the scenes--a challenge far beyond its capacity.

A small offering of bonus features becomes availabe at the end of the first playthrough, though these provide little incentive to return to the shopworn storyline.

Fans of novelty and experimentation will find some redeeming qualities in what Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ has accomplished, but anyone looking for a captivating narrative or a useful resource for planning a stay in Japan would be better served by almost anything else.

reviewText:
The title alone should hint that this isn't really a game, just a tourist brochure that tried to have an entertaining framework.

When compared to most Visual Novels, it has a lousy plot and does not flesh out the characters.  There's a long list of free VNs that boast great characterization and a deeper plot, and they even lack the perverted bits!

If you're a fan of Visual Novels, go buy Hate Plus or Analogue instead.  If you're a fan of Japanese Visual Novels (as opposed to Original English ones like this one), you'll be disappointed even further.

If you're looking for things to satiate your unspeakable desires, then this VN will also disappoint, I guarantee it.

Recommended audience:  the kind of people who REALLY want to go to Japan but have the funds for fork over $10, and can thus go to an art gallery featuring drawings of Japanese locales without the actual experience of being there.

reviewText:
Ok, i'll keep this short for those who don't want to read.
Art - 6/10
Kinda dissapointing, just the same cycle of images over and over along with a small amount of facial expressions. Google maps link is nice and innovative. Food sketches are rather pleasing however. The girls are nothing special and just serve to be usual cardboard cutout sisters recycled over and over as Japan is known famously for, the sweet heart kudere and the yandere.

Writing - 5/10
Does a good job of explaining Japan and it's culture. However there are some typos and some English saying's thrown in that serve no purpose and just seem completely off e.g. That's totally metal". Don't come in expecting voice acting
date:
because there is non! Furthermore the usual tropes are here that anyone would expect. It seems that all eastern women think western men think of nothing but engaging in sexual acts with anything that has a pulse. The gags are also terribly cringy and poorly implemented.

Story - 5/10
Sets out be a organised trip of Japan but ends up being more like an interactive propaganda video for Japan which isn't a problem in itself but this odd love narrative they try to string in is. It's all completely out of place considering they only did it to draw in a more pervese audience and give you a reason just to struggle through days if talking about Japanese history isn't you thing.

Gameplay - 1/10
What do you expect? Interactive slideshow. But if you like VN's then this is up your street.

Feels - 8/10
Characters grew on me like wart.

Vodka's Overall Rank - 7/10
Would only recommend to hardcore VN's lovers. If you want a real idea about Japan
recommended: go on a guided tour. Or read a book. You won't have to deal with annoying sisters who leave their door open so you can see their ♥♥♥ then put salt in your coffee."

reviewText: My experience with Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ was a rollercoaster of a ride. I learned a lot about Japan and the ways of the Japanese people. I appreciate the art and music that gently portrayed the calm and serene atmosphere in the Japanese cities and buildings that the story took place. The templates used for the characters did not feel outdated or stale which contributed to the overrall storyline in a positive way. It almost felt like I was there.\n\nI started off my adventure with choosing my name. I chose the clever and witty name of Onii-chan
date: which I have heard so many times in other Japanese mediums. An interesting design mechanism that the developers implemented was that all text in the story that was referring to me added Onii-chan". This enveloped as I felt like I was in the game. I can't believe the level of immersion that this game has presented to the market.\n\nThis game presented a twisted and joking tone right off the bat
recommended: as I was plunged into thinking I was going to "hang out with my bros" in Japan

reviewText:
Go Go Nippon was better than I expected. I heard it was educational and usually that doesn't mean much fun.

It is educutional and as a learning tool it would be good for learning to read some Japanese, speaking it probably not so much as there are no voice overs. Lots of Japanese history of Tokyo and Kanto regions.

Fear not it's also got 2 charming characters to keep you entertained. Though I found the younger sister (refraining from names simply to not spoil a minor detail) a bit cliche, Ironically I also liked her the most.
The older sister seemed more realistic.

It has some ecchi (not nudity just teaser stuff) scenes which at first took me out of the experience mainly because you get them rather early on, but I also felt the VN would have been a bit more boring without them...

Well if you hate VN's or just the Japanese culture in general (I have no idea why you are here then) then this probably won't change your mind. If you tend to like VN's then keep in mind this will be more educational than others which you might find less fun.

If you have an interest at all in learning the japanese culture and history it's great while also providing more entertainment than... well taking a class on Japanese =P.

reviewText:
As a novel, it is bad. There are little content, and none of them interesting to read. The waifu elements are bad too, there are zero dialogue choice, and the only thing that affects the ending are which 3 of the 6 locations you have chosen during the first 3 days.

I feel the author put a lot of effort into the game trying to balance out the informative element and waifu elements in it. But a lack of focus caused the game to be very uninteresting in both elements.

The girls are cute. But the artist seems to emphasize too much on the waifus, and didn't put enough effort into the enviroment. I, for one, would love to see and know more about Japan, which this game really lacks a lot of picures of. For one, when you first arrived to the airport, your tour guide will hand you a SUICA" card which are the prepaid card you will be using for a lot of places in this trip... without showing you at least a picture of the card itself.

All the things describe in this game that are supposed to be informative only touched the surface for each topics. Also
date: the tour guides treat you as a tourist from America/Europe
hoursPlayed: visitng Japan for the first time without any common knowledge about that place what-so-ever before arriving to the country.\n\nIt contains some useful information if you are planning to go to Japan for a tour some time soon
voteText: but a well-researched itinerary done on the internet is way better and more informative than this.\n\nMy score: 3/10"

reviewText: Right, I understand that you have to like visual novels in order to like this kind of game and, to me, this is barely a game at all. It is excrutiatingly boring and you do nothing but click on text to get to the next bit of text, some of the info is interesting though. Secondly, I don't know where that guy is from, he must have been living in a cave because he gets surprised at some many mondane stuff (even for an european player) that many times, it had me rolling my eyes. Speaking of story, I wish there was story to make fun of, this is the simplest of the simple story, a guy visiting Japan, period, your main character is dumb, one of the girl is nearly constantly ♥♥♥♥♥y and reproaching you the dumbest of things and the other is happy-go-lucky and that's it, no surprise, no carefully crafted characters and behavior. Not even the nudity makes up for the time lost in that thing. If you don't like visual novels, stay far away.

reviewText: I bought the game finally hoping for a deccent VN on Steam to play. (I have yet to play fading hearts & analogue a hate story though which both look like they'll be quite good.) The idea of being a tourist visting Japan is quite an interesting story idea as it fits alot of people like me and very possibly yourself! The story is fairly interesting, and all the sightseeing spots are also very interesting to read about and seem to be fairly accurate. All the normal feautres of most VN's are here and work well, and the interfaces are all made fairly well not too clunky. There's not really any H" scenes if that's your thing which is to expected of a game like this (definently on Steam) and really the game is better for not having any as it would take away from it I feel. For a VN, it's not bad in my opinion.
Exploring with 'internet friends' is a decent concept, and gives a few highlights of areas that most don't/won't care about initially.
I've played 3 of OverDrive's other works (with fan patches, or machine translation) and this one is actually better than the full out hentai games I've wasted 20+ hours on years ago.
Was a tad disappointed that this wasn't voiced like most VNs, but I can forgive that, since this was quickly made, and cheaply sold. (Hint: Dev's SHOULD update the Steam verson.)

reviewText: This is a game about going to Japan. As someone who visited Japan in the winter of 2010, I can say without a doubt that the game simulates the experience to a tee. In fact, one of my first experiences in Japan, and one of the earliest scenes in the game, was encountering the infamous “squirty” toilet, or a bidet as the locals call it. The first thing I do when I visit any hotel room is to examine the bathroom. I saw the toilet and was immediately awestruck by the array of buttons on a panel. I remember pressing a button with a water spout symbol, wondering what, if anything, would happen. And something happened indeed. From the middle of the toilet emerged a rod that sprayed water in an upward fashion: in the direction of my face. The experience was akin to drinking from a water fountain but much, much better, a truly wonderful sensation. Think of the hottest summer day in recent memory and remember uncapping that icy bottle of Poland Spring and pouring it all over yourself, no inhibition, nothing holding you back from such momentary release from the unrelenting heat. It was that good. I bring up this little anecdote because the game does that to you. It pulled from the deepest recesses of my memory the wonderful times I had in Japan. But it does something better. It brings you to Japan in the company of two girls  who host you in their own home. While I don’t remember much about the women in Japan, besides the Santa dressed girl who grimaced and said KYA! in my presence, I think it accurately portrays the inherent friendliness and outgoing nature of the Japanese people. Just make sure you have money and are willing to spend it. In this context, the game mirrors real Japan but removes the possibility of airsickness, hotel and food expenses, and arrest. Go! Live that long held off dream of visiting Japan and buy this game. You won't regret your first trip nor will your regret your next.

reviewText:
The game sells itself as a guidebook to Japan in the form of a visual novel. It is effective as an educational/informative tool to a point, but an actual guide book would be preferable as this is a somewhat limited and distracting format. At the least, some unfamiliar terms will be introduced, inviting further research on the part of the reader if they do want to make the investment of a trip to Japan later.

As an edutainment game in VN form, it accomplishes what it sets out to do. The plot is fairly weak and often takes a back seat to informative anecdotes, though the love story threads are very complimentary to grasping particular aspects of the culture. The protagonist is enough of a massive dork to elicit entertainment value, ironically or otherwise.

Production values, with regards to art and music, are all solid and with no major flaws. I question why the need was felt to include overt adult fanservice in this, as removing it would not affect the overall length in any major capacity.

I ended up enjoying this more than anticipated and find it recommendable as its own product. If you're interested in the culture of Japan, or like visual novels in general, you'll enjoy this. That said, it's worth acknowledging that it's not the most effective guidebook by any stretch of the imagination, and further reading is recommended; it has been catered to the VN-reading audience as an introduction, nothing more.

reviewText: After a long journey to Central America, I was conflicted on who i was and what i was doing. As i was basking in the sunlight, on a mere whim, i came across this game and added it to my wishlist. A dear, generous, short, indian, fragile, friend saw that it was nearing the day that i was born. He took this chance and bought me this game. I went home and saw that green email box on steam. I have never asked so many questions in my life, but i preceded to install this mystery. I came in with a delicate mind and casualness of a shota being violated by large 6 limbs stickey monstergirls and came out with a mindset of a rengar going into the eyes of the death without any stacks and just a single passive jump with 10%hp trying to steal a penta kill on live broadcast. The point of my review is to say you get what you expect. You get a trip to the land of no return. You will always remember that you have a game like this. It is a part of you and you must embrace it. Thus concludes my review. I must now go visit puru!n and fuku.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hodtacpLf_4
Ever felt like watching anime isn’t enough insight to what it’s actually like to visit Japan? Well enter your name, step into the shoes of the ultimate otaku stereotype and experience what it’s like to trick two young girls into letting you stay with them while you take in the sights of Japan.

The story revolves around spending a week in Japan and selecting one of several areas available to go visit. One of the girls you stay with will escort you to the area to narrate information about the location and sometimes get up to “wacky” escapades while there. While I can concede I didn’t know a lot of the stuff that was brought up, for me personally It was met with an “oh~” or “huh…”. Maybe the writers thought this was all way more interesting that I did or I’m just emotionally repressed (I am English afterall), but the protagonist takes any small piece of information and exclaims that it’s the most amazing thing he’s ever heard… Usually followed by a variation on “Only in Japan…”. This and the awkward dating sim parts really let the game down, because while funny the first few times, it permeates every day of the game and just becomes tiresome. Whether the writers honestly thought all tourists are like this, either through imagination or personal experience (fanboys *can* be creepy), I got really bored of reading it.

One of the neat touches in the game is that the dialogue prints out in japanese as well as english, so if you're learning the language you can follow along without having to manually switch between languages, or use a translation program. If aimed at people actually interested in learning the language or after ideas for places to visit during a trip, then the game actually does a pretty good job at achieving its goal. Sadly, the seedy, awkward dating sim side story going on that really detracts from that and seems to overtake the guide aspect as the focal point.

At first I didn't even actually believe this was going to have a dating aspect to it. Aside from the protagonist being creepy enough to send any sane girl fleeing in terror, it just doesn't really feel like the romance takes a natural progression. The whole premise of the game is that he's there just to take in the sights and be a humble little tourist, but after a few days he starts inner monologues about which sister he prefers and choosing" between them (because that's how true love works). This gives the game a really sinister vibe to it; that he’s there under false pretences to try and get together with one of the girls.

Visual novels pretty much live and die by the quality of their story and/or characters

reviewText:
This game.. I bought is as a joke so me and my friends can get a good laugh. We got through the first day, then he left. A couple of days later we got in a fight so I restarted the game and took it seriously. All I can say is if I ever have an exam on Japan/Tokyo I know I will pass it. Besides that point the game makes you feel alive and you really connect with the characters. When they were upset I got upset. The game made me cry, I NEVER cry. When I finished the game I did not want to cut it off. really i did not I felt as if i did I would be cutting my memories (me in the game). When Makoto says she loves you i could not do anything but cry in awe. This game changed me in a way that i will never forget. Now i fell a ache in my chest like something is missing.
~spoilers-
I was pretty upset when the credits rolled in I but then you go back to Japan a year later and you see her again. and then she says welcome home" at that point I knew the game was over but i wish it wasnt. Like i sad before I felt really connected the Makoto and Akira. I really did feel like i was staying at the house with them and traveling around japan. and the worst feeling leaving japan and leaving Makoto and Akira. I tried taking breaks from the game but i could not stop playing it. sure I know I'm going to get called gay from my friends but who cares. I love this game.

From a game that I bought as a joke and now stands as one of my favorite games of all time. 5/5 please buy."

reviewText: This is a game about going to Japan. As someone who visited Japan in the winter of 2010, I can say without a doubt that the game simulates the experience to a tee. In fact, one of my first experiences in Japan, and one of the earliest scenes in the game, was encountering the infamous “squirty” toilet, or a bidet as the locals call it. The first thing I do when I visit any hotel room is to examine the bathroom. I saw the toilet and was immediately awestruck by the array of buttons on a panel. I remember pressing a button with a water spout symbol, wondering what, if anything, would happen. And something happened indeed. From the middle of the toilet emerged a rod that sprayed water in an upward fashion: in the direction of my face. The experience was akin to drinking from a water fountain but much, much better, a truly wonderful sensation. Think of the hottest summer day in recent memory and remember uncapping that icy bottle of Poland Spring and pouring it all over yourself, no inhibition, nothing holding you back from such momentary release from the unrelenting heat. It was that good. I bring up this little anecdote because the game does that to you. It pulled from the deepest recesses of my memory the wonderful times I had in Japan. But it does something better. It brings you to Japan in the company of two girls  who host you in their own home. While I don’t remember much about the women in Japan, besides the Santa dressed girl who grimaced and said KYA! in my presence, I think it accurately portrays the inherent friendliness and outgoing nature of the Japanese people. Just make sure you have money and are willing to spend it. In this context, the game mirrors real Japan but removes the possibility of airsickness, hotel and food expenses, and arrest. Go! Live that long held off dream of visiting Japan and buy this game. You won't regret your first trip nor will your regret your next.

reviewText:
The game sells itself as a guidebook to Japan in the form of a visual novel. It is effective as an educational/informative tool to a point, but an actual guide book would be preferable as this is a somewhat limited and distracting format. At the least, some unfamiliar terms will be introduced, inviting further research on the part of the reader if they do want to make the investment of a trip to Japan later.

As an edutainment game in VN form, it accomplishes what it sets out to do. The plot is fairly weak and often takes a back seat to informative anecdotes, though the love story threads are very complimentary to grasping particular aspects of the culture. The protagonist is enough of a massive dork to elicit entertainment value, ironically or otherwise.

Production values, with regards to art and music, are all solid and with no major flaws. I question why the need was felt to include overt adult fanservice in this, as removing it would not affect the overall length in any major capacity.

I ended up enjoying this more than anticipated and find it recommendable as its own product. If you're interested in the culture of Japan, or like visual novels in general, you'll enjoy this. That said, it's worth acknowledging that it's not the most effective guidebook by any stretch of the imagination, and further reading is recommended; it has been catered to the VN-reading audience as an introduction, nothing more.

reviewText:
This isn't a tourist guide adventure, this is the daydream of a lonely, sexually-frustrated virgin.

The premise is that you visit Japan for the first time, staying with two dudes you met in a chatroom (you don't even know what they look like). But as soon as it turns out they're two sisters, and their parents just so happen to be out for a few weeks (I think the sisters murdered them, or there were never any parents and now they're going to murder you), the perv-o-meter goes to max.

This plot and how it plays out is basically the daydream of a very lonely, socially-inept guy. That's not an insult, but the way the girls act, fawning over you, boobs and panties, the stumbling and awkwardness of the male/you, if you have a love life (or are gay male or straight female) it's hard to relate to the closet-fedora-wearing protagonist.

It actually started off well, and seemed like a cool guide to the little details in Tokyo, useful bits to know if you ever go there. I'm a fan of the Tokyo-set Yakuza series, which is half megabucks AAA critically-acclaimed epic cinematic action RPG and half tourism simulator, and while I'm hardly some otaku whose watched anime and reads manga, this seemed like something that should appeal to me 'cause Japan is cool. But the tourism kinda takes a back seat to the intricate, dramatic plot of 'which girl will fight hardest to be my waifu?'

It was funny how the protagonist reacted to normal things. I'm from the UK and have visited London, so spazzing out over contactless pre-paid travel cards and 24-hour shops (that sell FOOD! And MAGAZINES! IN THE SAME STORE!! OMG!!!) was out of place.

Gameplay, there is none, no real interaction, so plot and visuals are important. None of that here. The plot is as above and the visuals are bare minimum drawings, where half of what's described isn't shown. The feature to include a Google Maps button is cool, but nothing amazing.

It all ends as you'd expect: one or both of the girls have declared their undying love for you, say how amazing you (some guy who's travelled half the world to have some company) are, and then you go back without having banged either of them. Because the internet-hermit virgin is a gentleman, who thinks girls are delicate flowers with feelings who want long-distance relationships in chatrooms, and not equally horny fiends who sometimes just want to [censored] a dude's [censored] while being [censored] on a futon.

I mean come on, two women find a guy on the internet, get him to come to their country and stay in their house all by themselves for a week. What's going to happen? Awkward stuttering over breakfast, shopping, and declarations of true love apparently...

reviewText: I mainly wanted to learn more about Japan since I am always interested in other cultures, and on top of that I do like otome games so this seemed like a nice combination...SEEMED yes...This game is...boring. Extremely cheesy, and boring.. The facts I was supposed to learn were either so long winded and boring I forgot them right away and the somewhat more fun ones were things that I already knew which, surprisingly the character whose supposed to be a weeaboo didn't even know... There are barely any interactive choices other than choosing what other boring lame place you'd go to this day and oh you can pick what food to eat once!! *Weeaboogasms* WOW SUGOI! *Insert sacastic snort here* The main character is seriously someone I could never place myself in and he annoys me. If I was in a gigantic manga section and I wanted to look at the adult doujinshi's and this girl was yelling at me that I am an idiot because she is embarrassed I'd tell her to go outside and wait till I am fricken done. Cause honestly, that would have been the ONLY thing that would have made this virtual trip to Japan at least somewhat satisfying. =_= And if I REALLY was able to look at that type of stuff while in Japan during my extremely short stay there, I sure as hell am not gonna let some failed tsundere tell me I can't.

reviewText:
Get ready to roll your eye's a lot if you play this game.

It's basically fanservice. It's Embarasing, almost painful, to watch a lot of the time; and I say watch because you're esentially dragged along without giving any input save one choice each day (well, really the first three days). The characters are completely without depth, kind of blank slates, except where they are extremely cliché or stupid. The main character is just painfully thickheaded.

There's some replayability value because you can't go to all of the places in one playthrough.
There's some useful information, it does feel kind of like a week in japan, you get a sense of the places you go to. But it's not really worth it for the poor dialogue and fanservice. I have been to Tokyo for a bit over a week and I think that the game gives you a pretty good feeling (albeit superficial) for what the places that they go to are like. The backgrounds/scenery is very good but I can't help but feel like for all the work that must have gone into the background paintings they could have made some more expressions for the characters.

Overall it's a great idea that lacks a lot in execution. If you're interested in Japanese culture, you'd be better off buying a good guidebook, learn the language and go there.

Overal did I enjoy playing the game? Yes, if only for the nostalgia of the places they go to.
Do I regret buying it? No... but there are better games for 4 euro.
Can I reccomend it to others? No, not with a clean conscience.

The fact that my profile says I played this, even if it was just for .2 hours, makes me wish I could just delete it. Maybe I can and I just haven't figured out how to remove it from my profile, but seriously it's just creepy, and god forbid someone else walks in on you playing this.

reviewText:
It says at the start that you'll only be at Japan for a week, so don't get your hopes for a good plot too high.
It doesn't lack anything, but keep in mind that this game's purpose is to present some useful information about Japan, and it can be a very interesting read if you happen to understand the language. While I don't like traveling nor do I know japanese, learning about part of it's history (the Edo period, mostly) and culture was quite interesting and enjoyable.

So, the game is not long, and it doesn't try to be the best Visual Novel out there, but if you're interesed in Japan culture, you will enjoy this VN.

reviewText:
Spectacularly awful 'game', which fails both on the visual and novel sides of the genre.

Half the time you just see a picture of the sky, and the actual pictures are for the most part entirely bland.

But it's the novel part that is the most awful, with such awful characterisation it is painful. The main character is unbearable, and seemingly incapable of normal conversation (not realised in such a way that would make it an interesting being-shy-simulator).

The only interesting thing is how Japanese their idea of how Westerners find Japan is. Of course they think that Japan is utterly unique, and we will be flumoxed by 24hr convenience stores and Oyster cards.

Beyond awful. I cannot fathom how anyone could possibly enjoy something this terrible. Ever. Oh God, it's terrible on every possible level.

reviewText:
Go! Go! Nippon is a visual novel game that has a lot going for it, but there are some things buyers might need to know before you buy it.

One- The price

At this current time the game is selling for 3.49 on steam, which is not bad for a visual novel game which takes around three to four hours to complete. However any  higher than this and I would suggest you wait for it to go on sale again.

Two- The story

The story of the game is a love story hidden within facts about Japan. It's not a bad story and if really do read all the text you do start to feel what the main character is going through. However don't expect to reply this game over and over. The story has two girls and two endings where you fall in love with one of them. That's it. Nothing more. A third play through might be in order if you would like to go to every location you can. But after that you might not play again.

Three-  Scene error

All visual novels have them, but here it's a little weird. At the very beginning of the story you land at the airport and are you can see your inside the airport lobby but then your main character says, That land mass below us  must be Japan!" A little weird. But after this most scenes are ok and you accept them for what they are. (At the price of £3.49 that is. Otherwise you can find better looking images on web created visual novels)

Four- Enjoyment

Go Go Nippon certainly is  an experience and  an education if you don't know a thing about japan.(Like me) Sure it's got the scenes where you walk in on the girls changing. But I guess if you're not really interested in learning about japan then you've got to get your enjoyment somewhere right? But don't be fooled by thinking love gets in the way of your learning. It doesn't. In fact you do learn a lot before the love story part begins.

So to end this review I would recommend Go! Go! Nippon! to anyone wanting to have a bit of fun while learning facts about japan. However if your just going to race through it to find the love scenes then perhaps it's not for you. The joy of this game i found is taking your time and ignoring the skip button. Because if you do
date: you'll feel and understand the special moments between the main character and the two girls. And that's not just from a love view-point
recommended: but from a friends on a trip view-point too.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed:
give it a try if your visual novel fan. It's not something you see everyday here on steam. Plus I think games like this focusing on other countries are entertaining and help give the player some history about the country.  I hope overdrive make more games like this about other countries as it's fun and interesting. But I also hope they think again about their pricing. Seven pounds for a game like this is a little steep. When there are visual novels out there that are free and give their player a little more to do.

My score for Go! Go! Nippon!

8/10"
